Pickering with opulent direction by the great George Cukor. The sets and production numbers are gorgeous. But see it for Audrey Hepburn, one of the great stars of the silver screen in one of her most memorable roles.(Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon!)

I'm not much of a fan of movie musicals. I mainly took a chance on this one because I knew that it was an influence on Seth MacFarlane of Family Guy fame, specifically in terms of the creation of the Stewie Griffin character. Now, having watched the movie, I am very glad that I did.Musically, the film is exceptional. There's no shortage of memorable melodies and all are augmented with clever lyrics. There are no throwaway songs, either. Whenever a character segues into song it is always relevant to the storyline.Likewise, the acting is top-notch. This is the role that Rex Harrison was born to play. Ditto Stanley Holloway. Audrey Hepburn is exquisite. I could go on but I'd end up listing just about everyone who had more than a few lines.The visuals are breathtaking. Among others, the movie won Oscars for Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Best Cinematography, Best Costume Design & Best Director, all of which were well-deserved.At the core of all of this is a compelling storyline that fills nearly three hours with ease. Outwardly, the film is a 'Cinderella story' though the script is rife with subtle commentary on class distinctions. However, the ending may put off some since it is deliberately vague. I don't think that there's a right answer to the question "What happens next?", though others are more than willing to jump to conclusions.To sum it up, this movie is proof of the old adage "They don't make 'em like they used to".

Review title: From the golden age of Musical
Review_body:
"My fair lady" (1964, George Cukor) is a film with a long history. It is inspired by the musical from 1956, which in turn was based on the play "Pygmalion" (1912, George Bernhard Shaw). Finally the name "Pygmalion" refers to an old Greek myth. In "My fair lady" Professor Higgins picks up a poor flower girl and makes a bet to his friend Pickering that he can change her (Cockney) accent so that she can show up on high society events like balls and the horse races of Ascot.I rewatched "My fair lady" in connection with "Pretty woman" (1990, Garry Marshall). In my memory the themes behind the two story's were very much the same. In "Pretty woman" the story can be summarized as follows.1) A man picks up a woman with a much lower social status.
2) This man tries to uplift / dignify this woman.
3) In the end she rather changes him instead of the other way around.Having seen "My fair lady" for the second time I have my doubts about the resemblance of the story lines. Only point 2 is clearly the same. Below some comments on the points 1 and 3.In "Pretty woman" the difference in social status (point 1) is mainly attributable to wealth. In "My fair lady" it seems to be education and maybe intelligence. On second thought however the difference in social status is due to a different accent. Given the fact that an accent is something you acquire at a young age and is then difficult to get rid of, this can be seen as a comment on the rigid English class society.In "Pretty woman" we have a perfect happy end with businessman Edward Lewis (Richard Gere) totally recovered from his greed (point 3). In "My fair lady" the end is much more ambiguous. Professor Higgins (Rex Harrison) is certainly missing his flowergirl turned into a lady Eliza (Audrey Hepburn), but is he missing his toy or is he missing the woman. His famous last line "Eliza? Where the devil are my slippers?" gives something to think about. The ending of the Greek myth of Pygmalion is less ambiguous than the film. The sculptor Pygmalion at first prefers to create a woman out of marble but than asks the Gods to change her in a woman of flesh and blood.The cast of the 1964 film was more or less the same as the cast of the 1956 musical, with one exception. Julie Andrews, playing Eliza in the musical, was thought to have too little film experience. She took revenge by winning an Oscar for her role in "Mary Poppins" (1964, Robert Stevenson). This unfortunate act of casting threws a shadow over the performance of Audrey Hepburn. In my opinion unjustified."My fair lady" has some marvelous songs in it, such as "Wouldn't it be lovely" and "With a little bit of luck" (to name just a few). Some songs have a habit of recurring in the course of the movie. "Wouldn.t it be lovely" is heared again when Eliza (as a lady) returns to the market where she used to sell flowers , and nobody recognizes her anymore. There are more instances of such symmetry, and they demonstrate how clever the film has been build up. When Eliza has her first appearance in the "high society", Higgins orders her to only talk about the weather. When Higgins and Eliza are having a fight at the end of the film the mother of Higgins orders him to only talk about the weather when she let the two of them alone.

"Your ending is damnable; you ought to be shot!" So boomed George Bernard Shaw, upon witnessing the ending of Pygmalion, his slashing satire of class and gender disparities, changed from its original intent. In Shaw's words, leading lady Eliza Doolittle ended the play by proudly walking out on Professor Henry Higgins, her sneering tutor. To Shaw's chagrin, subsequent performances had twisted the climax into a more populist, albeit disingenuously romantic, 'happy ending.' Flash-forward forty years, by the time My Fair Lady, the filmic revival of the now beloved Broadway musical, was released, audiences would have expected nothing less. And yet, for a show heralded as "the perfect musical," it's startling how, nostalgic haze aside, how many of the film's attributes have aged poorly to the point of being resoundingly un-fair - none the least, that 'damnable' ending itself. This isn't to say that the film is worthy of the kind of lambasting Higgins bestows upon Eliza, upon first glimpsing her in her unrefined, working class inelegance (ahh, romance). Granted, for one of the defining directors of the Classical Hollywood screwball era, George Cukor's work here is thoroughly sleepy, with the skeletal plot lumbering along with such an unhurried dopiness that an hour could easily have been shaved off the running time without batting an eye. Even the songs, unforgettably catchy as they are, are staged with an oddly docile tentativeness. Even the most iconic tunes come across as shy and tentative rather than the lively vivaciousness they warrant. Where Cukor really perks up is in mischievously digging into the show's social critique, lambasting English high society's priggish, disinterested disdain for the less fortunate with gleeful abandon. Sure, the endless montages of Higgins' antiquated speech language pathology turned sadistic psychological torture bring their share of comedic relief, but the film's brightest, most engaging moment is its central horse race scene, where droves of virtually sleepwalking society men and women raise and lower their opera glasses in synch like cows chewing their cuds, just waiting to be shaken up by Eliza Doolittle's feisty bull in a china shop. Similarly, Cukor spares no expense in costume and set design, as the two diametrically opposed social stations - the grungy London ghetto and prim society balls - look gorgeously, spectacularly vivid in their own respects. Tranquilized execution or not, there's no denying the film's 'loverlyness,' and it carries enough charm to keep afloat, especially when punctuated by welcome moments of acrid, Shawsian wit. Ah yes - but then there's that romance, boldly paving the way for decades of romanticized unhealthy relationships in a way that even Grease's 'change everything for your man!' climax would shudder at. It's certainly no fault of the performers. Hepburn herself is an absolute effervescent delight, as Eliza's course roots allow her to gleefully cast off her tried and true airs of consummate elegance with a hysterical, sparky firebrand of a performance, Monty Python cockney accent and all (it's a shame she wasn't allowed to contribute her own singing, as the unnecessary dubbing during musical numbers is detrimentally distracting). Similarly, Rex Harrison's nimble elocution and pristinely condescending eyebrows light up Henry Higgins' monolithic misogyny with a sneering charisma that makes him distressingly hard to hate, even at his most loathsome. In fact, therein lies the film's most unshakeable concern: Higgins is so farcically abhorrent to Eliza throughout that it's impossible for his third act romantic about-face not to play as just as grotesque, abusive and controlling. Different direction or actor interpretation could have teased out nuances of redemptive shame in Higgins' transformation (there's even an arguable undercurrent of Higgins as a closeted homosexual fighting for societal or matriarchal validation through heteronormative normalcy - "Why can't a woman be more like a man," anyone?). Instead, Harrison plays him as so deliciously, unrelentingly despicably throughout that we're eager for him to get a colossal comeuppance, not a simperingly happy ending. Seldom has so sharp and sweet a film ended on such an uncomfortably false note - even Hepburn's face and body language are saturated with this uneasiness in her purportedly cute final appearance - and it can't help but taint the entire film as consequence. Loverly 'dis ain't. Guaarrn. This isn't all to say that your childhood is ruined, and My Fair Lady is an unredeemable write-off - it's fun, frilly, and peppered with moments both delightful and dastardly witty. Still, contemporary gender politics haven't been kind to this one, and it's important to contextualize how uneasy and unsatisfying a watch the film is amidst its many delights. We've grown accustomed to its face, but that shouldn't excuse the scowl it works hard to hide under its prettiness. -6/10

Review title: A Sow's Ear out of a Silk Purse...
Review_body: A Professor of Misogyny takes advantage of a young woman and turns her into something she isn't. It's similar to the treatment forced on those whose sexual orientation didn't conform to the views of the 'holier than thou', and therein lies the paradox, with the prof and his colonel chum. Weighing in at an almighty 170 minutes, you can remove Eliza's father from the scene as he adds nothing to the story, excepting a song about the imminent demise of an individuals freedom. Nothing wrong with Eliza's aspirations and Audrey Hepburn is delightful, although it was education not enunciation she needed and, after twenty years without a bath, delicing, steroids and some powerful antibiotics. How about - My Equality Lady, now wouldn't that be luverly.

Review title: A shining musical example - but no-one makes them any more
Review_body: Well, this is definitely my favourite musical. Forty years after it was released it still sparkles. The negative was restored in 1994 and it was a new print that I saw recently on TV. In devising the lyrics Alan J Lerner stuck fairly closely to the original "Pygmalion" script, thus much as Shaw would have hated it, his astringent words are sung as much as they are spoke. The movie is virtually the 1956 stage musical filmed, but George Cukor gives it a sheen a Broadway producer would be hard put to emulate (not to mention real horses at Ascot).Rex Harrison as Higgins was as I remember him, supremely self-confident and self-centred, with very hardworking eyebrows. But Audrey Hepburn as Eliza, who is not a very convincing flower girl, is more beautiful than I remember, and she is a real lady when the time comes for her to be one. There is almost too much Alfred Doolittle, though he has a couple of the best songs, but the great music hall veteran Stanley Holloway has the role down pat. As for the rest of the cast, they are all fine.My only beef is about the ending. In "Pygmalion" as first produced as a play in 1914, Eliza does not return to Henry Higgins, but goes off to marry the handsome, love-struck but vacuous Freddy. Shaw explained this in a postscript. When "Pygmalion' was filmed by Gabriel Pascal in 1937, this ending was altered so that in the last scene so that Eliza appears at the doorway just as Henry is hunting for his slippers. Shaw, it seems, hated this but permitted it because at least there was the possibility she might not stay. In My "Fair Lady" this second ending is used, but somehow Eliza seems to be back for good.I think Shaw got it right. Eliza and Henry are not a romantic couple. Apart from the age gap, he is such a vain and self-centred man that only a woman who wanted to be a doormat would consider him. Eliza is tough, streetwise and assertive. The relationship would be a disaster. On the other hand, she and Freddy the male bimbo could be very happy together if they could achieve some financial security. With Pickering's help there could be a flower shop, the business Eliza knows so well, and there would be no need for Freddy to run off with a social climbing heiress from New York.It amazes me how well this production, campy and mannered though it is, stands up after 40 years. It has "good bones"  Shaw's basic plot  Lowe's excellent music, fine acting and truly great production values. The day of the musical seems to be long over, but this film continues as a shining example of the genre. Never did three hours go so fast.

Review title: Magical Adaptation of One of the Best Broadway Musicals of All Time
Review_body: Among the many Hollywood efforts to convert Broadway hit musicals into movies, the best adaptation of them all may be "My Fair Lady". And, believe it or not, the success of the movie may be in large part due to Cary Grant--not for what he did but for what he didn't do. The studio originally wanted Grant as Prof Higgins rather than Rex Harrison. (They had already passed on Julie Andrews as Eliza.) However, Grant insisted that Harrison, who so convincingly played the brilliant but amoral professor of phonetics in the original Broadway stage production, was the hands down choice for the part. Grant also threatened that if they didn't cast Harrison, the screen icon would never work for Hollywood again! Sometimes Hollywood has to be nudged a little to make the appropriate decision.The fact is, without Harrison, the movie would have suffered. Instead, what lives on today is a movie musical that is as fresh, funny, and insightful as it was 40 years ago at its release. At first glance, the premise is a kind of Cinderella story with a brash self-centered professor as the Fairy Godmother. The movie centers around a lower-class flower girl from East London, Eliza Dolittle played with dazzling innocent charm by the incomparable Audrey Hepburn, who sports a brash cockney accent that could give Frankenstein's monster a run for his money. The story is about her transformation from lower-class insignificant into upper-class "lady" of substance that can handle herself at social functions, mainly as the result of language lessons from a heartless scholar of phonetics.Behind this seemingly tame premise, originally written with caustic wit by the inventive George Bernard Shaw, is a biting satire on relationships, the meaning and power of phonetics, and the inequities of class in early 20th-century England. Many of the themes of "My Fair Lady" hearken back to prejudice, and how speech may open or close doors of particular social circles.The most unsympathetic character is Professor Henry Higgins, who accepts the challenge to work with Eliza. His lack of empathy for the uneducated Eliza is as brash as her cockney speech. He pushes her beyond reasonable limits and exhibits not a shred of kindness toward his pupil. Tempering Higgins is the honorable Colonel Pickering who appears the only character to truly empathize with Eliza's difficulties and tries to persuade the professor not to push the girl beyond her capabilities. In the end, Eliza comes to respect Pickering much more than Higgins. To his credit, Higgins despises the class distinctions and expresses his distaste for the cockney accent as a means of identifying those in the lower class with the song "Why Can't the English Learn to Speak?" Simultaneously, when Hepburn begins to succeed at her task, Higgins gives all the credit to himself and some to Pickering, as if they were solely responsible for Eliza's transformation. They act as if Eliza had nothing to with it.The story works just about every level. The only sequence that is overlong and has little to do with the story concerns Eliza's father, Alfred Dolittle, getting married in an endless number called "Get Me to the Church on Time". Why is it that the most pointless numbers of movie musicals always seem to be the longest? Screen adaptations of Broadway hit musicals have been largely a mixed bunch with some recapturing the wonder of the magic of the original live production while others have fallen agonizingly short. The movie equivalent of "Oaklahoma", "The Sound of Music", and "Fiddler on the Roof" rank among the better adaptations. "The Man of La Mancha", "Camelot", and "Westside Story" failed to reprise on the large screen the enchanting brilliance that occurred on stage. Often these are due to compromises in either the original script and/or the talent. The movie "Camelot" changed the tone and some of the script of the original show and recast Richard Harris in the lead as King Arthur instead of Richard Burton. Peter O'Toole had remarked on the inadequacy of the sets of "Man of La Mancha". And many have criticized the film adaption of "West Side Story" as misrepresenting the Puerto Ricans. As it is, My Fair Lady reigns as one of the best of all time.

My Fair Lady is tops.  It's hard to think of any way the film could be improved.  Just leave it as it is, don't worry about 'political correctness' and enjoy yourself.  You'll be humming the show tunes for weeks.

Henry hates women. He is a mama's boy.This show is about a woman, but Henry wants to snag all the applause. He is snotty to women of what he thinks is the lower class.Henry is old, but unmarried and childless. Who could live with him, anyway? Mama tries to set him straight, but he is too stubborn.Henry is an obnoxious, selfish misogynist. His life revolves around his bratty self. Pygmalion, indeed. Pulling the strings, eh? End of my rant about stupid Henry Higgins.Now on to my observations about lovely Audrey Hepburn. Her pink outfit and matching hat are just divine. Freddy is a really cute number. Eliza jumps all over the vegetable cart with such divine movement and timing. She is joyously happy to be alive.Eliza's white ball costume is just divine. Her hair updo is just scrumptious. She even convinces the Theodore Bikel character that she is real royalty (???). I think Eliza surprised Henry and Colonel Pickering more than they thought that she would. Their creation became super popular. Henry and Pickering who? Pickering was an actual gentleman, opposed to Henry who was a childish, spoiled brat.Final scene: Henry ordering Eliza around, to pick up his slippers. What a moron. Get them yourself, you stupid idiot. Whatsa matter? Mama not around to pick up after you? Get a life. Who would want to marry you, anyway? I still liked this movie. It is a family favorite, for eons. The flower girl did succeed in shoveling it to old Henry. She was capable of being out on her own now.From clothing, I would guess the time period would be around 1910-1912. World War One was just around the corner. Henry would have still been studying obscure dialects, lost in his goofy nitwit cloud of oblivious nonchalance.The singing and dancing: you know that they are my favorites. So what if some singing is dubbed. It is still a wonderful show. Some characters even talked-sang.Still a 10/10.

Review title: One of the screen's joyous achievements, an elegant musical filled with adult characters who think before they speak.
Review_body: The film is a musical version of Pygmalion, about a flower girl (Audrey Hepburn) trained by an arrogant elocutionist (Rex Harrison) to pass as a lady.My Fair Lady is a careful, cold transcription of a stage success; cinematically quite uninventive when compared with Pygmalion itself, but it's sumptuously presented, with opulent sets and Cecil Beaton's astonishing costumes. Harrison is as authoritative here as he had been throughout the musical's long stage run; Hepburn, somewhat shaky as a cockney flower girl, comes into her own with a vengeance in the second half, when she becomes a lady. And of course, a good three-quarters of the songs are unforgettable. The film won eight Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Actor, and Best Director.

1964's My Fair Lady is one joyful musical and that may be too negative of a description. It certainly deserves all the accolades it received in 1964-1965 and even today. It's a magical, romantic movie about how opposites attract. It's very weird to call this movie a romance because of the actions that take place in the film. There are no kisses, no wooing, none of that fancy stuff.....but undeniably, love is in the air. The songs are enchanting and the performances from Rex Harrison and Audrey Hepburn are nothing short of fantastic. Sure, modernists may raise some issues about Harrison's treatment of Hepburn's character, but this is how it was back during these times. Even so, there are some creative lines of dialogue that makes Harrison's character a bit more sympathetic.Many of you may not know this, but this film has some Greek story behind these words and songs. Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Lowe adapted this story from the 1912 film, Pygmalion. That film had a story that started as a Greek legend and retold in every era, all the way until the present 1964 feature. The music these gentlemen created for the movie are memorable in their own way. Two songs stand out. "Wouldn't It Be Loverly," which is about the dreams of Eliza (played by Hepburn) and the one song that everyone knows, "The Rain in Spain..." which is a triumphal duet between the main characters.The movie also had an expert director overseeing the movie. This director is none other than George Cukor. He made this film vibrant and dazzling as he possibly could have. The colors will catch your eye, and the beauty of the set design would want you to embrace this world with your own imagination. I also loved the costumes. When we see Eliza portrayed as an upper-class woman for the first time, my mind was absolutely blown away. Her dress is magnificent!The premise of the movie is actually quite simple. Professor Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) is a misanthrope which essentially means he dislikes everyone and everything! But the biggest thing (or person) that gets on his nerve is the dirty, cockney flower girl, Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn). He despises the way she speaks and the way she mispronounces words, in his harsh opinion. He takes a bet from his good friend Colonel Hugh Pickering (Wilford Hyde-White). This bet forces the Professor to try and turn Eliza into a lady. If he succeeds, what will high society think of her? Will Higgins be less disdainful?The performances from both Rex Harrison and Audrey Hepburn are magical. Their characters are complete opposites yet they both have wonderful chemistry together. Despite their strong performances, it does take some time to get used to them. You may be familiar with Rex Harrison from the original Doctor Dolittle film and he is a great actor, but it is kind of hard to get behind such a selfish character at first. Audrey Hepburn is beautiful, but one can admit her original Cockney accent is a little irritable. But the performances from these two were able to wash away any concerns I had. I also thought Wilford Hyde-White provided some witty banter and also Gladys Cooper as Higgin's mother also delivers a great performance.There is some good trivia associated with the movie and the biggest trivia fact is that Audrey Hepburn does not do her own singing except during a small reprise. Her voice was not deemed good enough for the film so there was a stand-in who did all the singing. That said, the music is great. The songs are cheerful, melodic, and extremely memorable.I am not a linguist (even though I studied basic linguistics) and I know teaching accents/vocabulary is not something that happens overnight, so be prepared to bring some imagination into the film. This is an old-school musical about love-and one that is not even seen in Hollywood these days. In fact, the political spectrum (involving Stanley Holloway as Eliza's poor father) would have been cut. Admittedly, I did find myself charmed with the politics.If you like musicals, bright and colorful films, long films, or all of the above, then The Fair Lady is the film for you. It may not be to everyone's taste, but it certainly gave me something to remember!My Grade: A-

Musicals were on the verge of becoming a dying genre,yet in the final years of their heyday,the 1960's,some of the best musical films in cinema history were produced.Anyone can make a strong case for My Fair Lady.It is a virtual textbook on how to make a musical film.It has songs that will have you humming for the rest of the day and night,it has sharp,intelligent dialog delivered by wonderful performers.The cinematography is spectacular.It's nearly flawless.I have no doubt that it took more work to make this type of film than any other kind,and the hard work that was put into My Fair Lady gave everyone involved in making it countless rewards.Bravo! Well done!

George Cukor had a long distinguished career in Hollywood, culminating in achieving almost unanimous critical and huge commercial success with this extremely faithful adaption of the enormously successful Broadway musical; itself based on George Bernard Shaw's play Pygmalion. After winning 8 Academy Awards including best picture and director, many would support the contention, that this success was entirely justified and overdue, considering his earlier arguably unfair sacking from Gone With the Wind by producer David O Selznick, after contributing greatly to its production.Cukor had a reputation for eliciting fine performances from his leads and My Fair Lady is no exception. The almost 3 hour film is dominated by the characters of grumpy linguist Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) and socially aspiring street urchin come flower girl, Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn), who both excel in the ultimate romance realised after an extended comic, gender warfare scenario. Hepburn was widely criticised for being cast instead of Julie Andrews, a far superior singer famed for making the stage role of Eliza her own, though never accepted as film star material by producer Jack L Warner. No matter! Even though Andrews' angelic voice is missed by those familiar with the extremely popular Broadway recording, Hepburn's acting skills in interpreting the transformation of Eliza from whiney Cockney to a resplendent, independently-thinking woman cannot be faulted.The production and art design is outstanding in a film that features no exteriors. All the London locations are recreated impressively on Warner Bros sound stages. But crucially Cukor and his team which included cinematographer Harry Stradling Snr and Art Director/Costume Designer Cecil Beaton, avoid giving the impression, the production is just a filmed play. Instead they create the perfect environments to record memorable musical and mannered dancing sequences such as the Ascot Gavette and the Ambassador's Ball, where Lerner's and Lowe's songs are supremely realised in sumptuous settings, peopled with a cast invariably stylishly and alluringly and colourfully costumed.One point of criticism may be made around the film's pace. Much as Stanley Holloway's Alfie Doolittle is beloved, as are his two featured song and dance numbers, his extended songless interlude at Higgins's house in an attempt to extort money, has little really to do with the main storyline and means the charismatic Hepburn is offscreen for an appreciably noticeable time. One feels more refined editing may have limited this dead time and moved the story along more fluidly. It does beg the question of how faithful a film needs to be, of its stage musical roots?However the years have failed to dim the brightness of Cukor's achievement in creating a lasting Hollywood technicolor spectacle of irresistible music and song with a lightly satirical sub-text at English upper class expense. Without doubt, one of the great movie musicals!

Review title: I really wanted to like this film
Review_body: 'My Fair Lady' is a musical re-working of Bernard Shaw's play 'Pygmalion'. Starring the lovely Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison, and with direction by George Cukor, it was always going to be a big hit, but I for one do not consider this up there with the best musicals of all time.For one thing, it is much too long. The run time is close to three hours, and the exuberance and spontaneity of musicals always seem to wear off after the two hour mark. The production values are magnificent though, the songs are superb and it is entertaining enough to watch for 170 minutes. A family favourite because it really is a 'nice' film, it also sadly misses the point of Shaw's original play. Shaw's aim was to show the class divide in England through the placement of the Cockney flower girl, Eliza Doolittle (Hepburn), in upper-class English society, a territory she is unfamiliar with. Through Henry Higgins' (Harrison) bet that he can make a lady out of a common wench, Eliza is plucked off the streets and transformed into an elegant 'lady'.I've always disliked the presentation of the poor in these things as gloriously happy, sing-song people who are ignorantly happy with their lot- exactly the way they are portrayed herethrough song and dance numbers.This also becomes less about class and wealth and more about romance,so that disappointed me too. It is a sharp script, yet there is hardly any truly biting social commentary.Hepburn's performance is alright to good, without being exceptional. She simply was too glamorous and upper-crust to play the Cockney girl, and her accent is quite bad. Her songs are dubbed in too, so she's not actually singing here, folks. Harrison looks old next to Hepburn but his performance is much better than hers, he won the Academy Award for it. It is notable that they don't actually lock lips in this one, but the romance is there. The costumes are terrific, and Hepburn starts to hit her stride reasonably well when she is back in her usual glamour clothes, but there is nothing approaching her best work here.Still, audiences continue to love this film, so it can't be really bad. Perhaps we all just love seeing an ugly duckling to beautiful swan (though how Hepburn can ever be perceived as ugly is beyond me)transformation, it satisfies the romantic in all of us.6/10.

The two best things about this musical are Rex Harrison's (Cleopatra) masterful performance and its avoidance of a conventional ending. The sets, costumes, and stages are also a visual marvel and the supporting roles were also perfectly cast. Being a fan of dialogue driven movies, I must also add that the verbose musings of the main characters was a pure delight. 8/10.

My Fair Lady, the musical from 1964, directed by George Cukor, is a remake of the movie Pygmalion from 1938 with Wendy Hiller and Lesley Howard. Based on the George Bernard Shaw play, this musical extravaganza deals primarily with the relationship between Henry Higgins, a linguistics professor played by Rex Harrison, and Eliza Doolittle, a Covent Garden flower vendor, Audrey Hepburn. In taking charge of Eliza and teaching her how to speak "proper English" Henry shows an attitude of superiority towards the working classes whose "cold blooded murder of the English tongue" rule out any possibilities for social mobility. To make matters worse, he has no idea of how to properly court a woman, thus making him a confirmed bachelor. However, he meets his match in Eliza, who is no slouch when it comes to handling men.
The first half of the movie is too long and becomes a little tedious. After a social disaster at the annual Royal Ascot horse-racing event, the pace picks up and the viewer is in for quite a treat. The costumes, stage sets and dancing are delightful. The cast is excellent. Aside from Rex Harrison and Audrey Hepburn, there are stalwarts such as Wilfrid Hyde-White as Colonel Pickering, Gladys Cooper as the mother, who doesn't hesitate to give her son a piece of her mind, Stanley Holloway as Eliza's much-loved father and Mona Washbourne as Higgins' efficient housekeeper. The role of Freddy, who falls deeply in love with Eliza, is performed by Jeremy Brett, who later on in his career, makes his mark as Sherlock Holmes.
This movie may seem dated but in the end is one well worth viewing and shows George Bernard Shaw's astute view of Edwardian England.

My Fair Lady (1964): Starring Rex Harrison, Audrey Hepburn, Wilfrid Hyde-White, Stanley Holloway, Gladys Cooper, Jeremy Brett, Theodore Bikel, Mona Washbourne, Isobel Elsom, John Holland, Mary Alexander, Helen Albrecht, Frank Baker, Lois Battle, Brittania Beatey, William Beckley, Iris Bristol, Sue Bronson, Andrew Brown, Buddy Bryant, Walter Burke, Jennifer Crier, Roy Dean, Henry Daniell, Thomas Dick, Brendan Dillon, Moyna MacGill, Alan Napier, Charles E. Fredericks With Marni Nixon (uncredited singer dubbing for Audrey Hepburn)...Director George Cukor, Screenplay and Lyrics By Alan Jay Lerner, Based On The play "Pygmalion" by George Bernard Shaw."Just you wait Henry Higgins! Just you wait!"......The 60's was still a time when the Broadway musical ruled, both on stage and on the big screen. This flowery and "flower power" decade would still see such musicals on film as "Westside Story" ('61) "The Sound Of Music" ('65), "Camelot" ('67) and "Oliver" ('68). It came as no surprise that Warner Bros released "My Fair Lady", based on the old play "Pygmalion" by George Bernard Shaw. It was already the subject of a film from at least 30 years before and not to mention the biggest hit on Broadway at the time. It was Warner Brothers' most expensive film and producer Jack Warner's last great movie musical, as well as his prestige picture. The film was still in production when President John F. Kennedy was shot. The premise: A millionaire, well-educated language professor makes a bet that he can pass a street-walking flower peddler as an aristocratic and sophisticated lady. The original London cast had starred the legendary musical star Julie Andrews, for whom the role of Eliza Doolittle was written. But she was not star in the film version because director George Cukor, Warner Bros and Hollywood felt that Julie Andrews (who had only appeared in Mary Poppins by then) and had not yet finished filming "The Sound of Music", had no real star power to attract audiences. So they gave the role to none other than Audrey Hepburn. To be fair, the role should have gone to Julie Andrews, who would have been off to a great success on film with this role but Audrey Hepburn was still a very bankable star at this time and audiences flocked to see her films, especially after successfully different films like "War And Peace", "A Nun's Story", "Green Mansions" and "Breakfast At Tiffany's". But Warner Bros felt (wrongfully) that Julie Andrews was no real star and it would have made their movie into a flop if she had been cast. Hepburn's speaking parts (the singing voice belonged to Marni Nixon, who had dubbed for other stars in several musicals on film such as "The King and I" and "Westside Story") reveal her dramatic talent and her dedication to vividly portraying a Cockney flower girl, complete with the accent and dirty looks, who becomes her own woman after an education by the Professor, whom she loathes. As Liza she is terrific. Even now, no one can see another actress, not even the great Julie Andrews, as Liza in this film. It's interesting to note that, despite Marni Nixon She may be overdoing the Cockney accent and attitude, but her performance in the last part of the film is amazing, even Oscar-worthy. She has changed from street-bred, dirty and low-class flower seller to beautiful, elegant and sophisticated glamor girl. For Hepburn, such transformations on film were as easy to do as breathing, for she had already done the "ugly duckling/swan" bit in films that brought her success- "Sabrina" ('54) and "Funny Face" ('57). British star Rex Harrison as the rich, well-educated, sexist, pompous, imperious language professor Henry Higgins is superb. He wasn't much of a singer but the role didn't call for the flowery- lyric singing provided by Liza's character and he is mostly a "talky" kind of singer. The part was tailor-made for his type of acting. His chemistry with Hepburn is simply perfect. With Andrews, it would not have been the same (although some would disagree for both Harrison and Andrews were terrific on the stage) but there is no denying the chemistry between Harrison and Hepburn. Harrison oozes cynicism and a sort of old-fashioned masculinity which is well-matched with Hepburn's eventual resourcefulness, classiness, willful spirit and inner fire. When she finally wins his bet for him, she feels cheated, betrayed and hurt. Now, with her new-found education which itself brings the power to take life into her own hands, she lashes out on Professor Higgins and reveals she is no longer dependent on him or anyone. That moment in the end is Hepburn's greatest achievement on film. She had hoped to win her second Oscar but ironically lost to Julie Andrews (for her role as Mary Poppins) who proved to everyone, including Warner Bros who had snubbed her, that she was indeed star material. With Oscar winning cinematography by Harry Stradling and gorgeous as well as costly costumes by Cecil Beaton, this film is a winner. The memorable songs from this musical include: "The Rain In Spain", "Would'nt It Be Lovely" "Just You Wait Henry Higgins" "Get Me To The Church" and "I Could Have Danced All night". Interesting side not: Although Marni Nixon, trained operatically and on Broadway, sang most of the songs (because Hepburn's voice was small and not capable of reaching the high notes), Audrey Hepburn did in fact sing some portions of the songs, including "Wouldnt It Be Lovely" "Just You Wait Henry Higgins" and "Show Me".

My Fair Lady is an excellent film with lots of lavish production value and good acting. The characters are good too, Higgins is for most of the time a pompous ass and Colonel Pickering is a bumbling fool. In fact the only character with a complete personality is Eliza Doolittle. Higgins teaches Eliza to improve her speech and she tries to teach him decency and to awaken his better nature.The songs are very memorable (Rain in Spain, Just you wait etc) and even though Audrey Hepburn's voice is dubbed (much to her apparent annoyance) it's still good.9/10: Quite a lengthy film but it's well made and uses its runtime well

Review title: A Classic Musical makes a practically seamless transition to the screen...
Review_body: MY FAIR LADY is the 1964 film version of the Lerner and Lowe Broadway musical, based on Shaw's PYGMAILION, that won nine Academy Awards, including Best Picture, beating out films like MARY POPPINS and DR. STRANGELOVE and finally garnering a Best Director Oscar for the legendary George Cukor. For those who've been living under a rock since the 1960's, this is the story of a cockney flower girl named Eliza Doolittle who is transformed into a sophisticated lady through the art of learning how to speak properly by a phonetics professor named Henry Higgins. Rex Harrison won the Best Actor Oscar for recreating his Broadway role as Professor Higgins, the confirmed bachelor who allows his new creation to get under his skin. Eyebrows were raised in Hollywood when the role of Eliza Doolittle went to Audrey Hepburn, instead of the role's originator, Julie Andrews, who earned sweet revenge by winning the Best Actress Oscar the same year for MARY POPPINS. Hepburn is lovely as the transformed Eliza, but is less convincing as the dirty-faced cockney flower girl. Hepburn's singing was dubbed by Marni Nixon, who also sang for Natalie Wood in WEST SIDE STORY and for Deborah Kerr in THE KING & I. Wilfred Hyde-White and Gladys Cooper provide solid support as Higgins' friend who helps with the transformation and as Higgins' mother, who befriends Eliza when she really needs a friend. This movie is exquisitely mounted, with Oscar-winning production design and stunning, Oscar-winning costumes by Cecil Beaton. The original score to the musical comes to the screen almost completely intact, highlights being "Wouldn't it be Loverly", "I've Grown Accustomed to her Face", "I Could Have Danced All Night" and "Just You Wait." This is a textbook example of how to bring a Broadway musical to the screen. A joy from start to finish.

Review title: Opulent, Charming and Captivating; A Very-Intelligent Late Musical
Review_body: This film is famous for the preceding history it boasted as a fine play and successful film "Pygmalion" written by perverse major-talent playwright George Bernard Shaw; for the opulent production accorded its production by MGM's executives; and for the controversy surrounding the handing of its female lead to Audrey Hepburn and not to its its Broadway leading lady Julie Andrews; for the strange choices made in awarding other roles to less-than-ideal choices; and for the lovely musical additions by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederic Loewe that are perhaps more celebrated by now than even the musical film itself--numbers such as ""Why Can't the English Teach Their Children How to Speak", "With a Little Bit o' Luck", "Wouldn't It Be Loverly", "The Rain in Spain", "Let a Woman in Your Life", "On the Street Where You Love", "I Could Have Danced All Night", "Get Me to the Church On Time" and The Ascot Gavotte", Show Me" and "I've Grown Accustomed To Face", among others. The story-line of the original play is retained; and it is relatively simple. Professor of phonetics Henry Higgins encounters a colleague from India, Colonel Pickering who has come to see him, on a street outside a major theater. He criticizes a flower-girl's speech, remarking offhandedly that in six months he could her off as a lady--or a shop girl, which requires better English; that it is her accent which keeps her in lower-class poverty. The girl comes the next day, to his home where Higgins is entertaining his new guest, and offers to pay for training. Higgins is a social monster and frightens the girl with his rough talk, but he agrees to take her on, and sends her to his housekeeper to be given a bath and have her clothes burned and replaced--which act turns out to precipitate a major battle... At one point, her ne'er-do-well father, Alfred P. Doolittle, demands money to overlook the Professor's theft of his daughter, Eliza, meaning the income she had provided him; he uses the money to get married. The training proves difficult and arduous; Higgins' mother is amused and frightened by the experiment, set off by Pickering's wagering Higgins could not train the girl. But he does; Eliza proves to be bright, touchy, emotional and altogether more interesting than Higgins had expected. She succeeds, masters an upper-class accent; and then in rapid succession, she is presented at a party to social highbrows where her accent is perfect but the content of her speech is Cockney matters, which they take for a fashionable new court slang, and then she upsets the Ascot Race Meeting crying to the horse she has bet on, "Move yer bloomin' arse!", but charms Freddie Eynesford-Hill who becomes her shy suitor. At last the Professor presents her at a a royal ball where she charms everyone concerned, avoids any major faux pas, and convinces a bogus Hungarian phoneticist she must be royal herself. So the experiment has succeeded; Higgins has won his bet. Then he discovers, as a distraught Eliza confronts him the next day, that he has done what he had set out to do--he has created a person capable of self-assertion in the world, but not in the flawed British Empire's stratified and totalitarian society. She leaves him, to marry Freddy; and he discovers he has fallen in love with her. She recognizes that Freddy is unworthy of her and, despite the lack of promises and guarantees from Higgins, returns to do battle with him--for the rest of their lives, perhaps. The entire production looks unarguably lovely, even the Covent Garden faked scene, and a very difficult mixture of faked outdoor and elaborate indoor settings it must have been. Director George Cukor, famed for his skill with actors, gets a near-perfect job of acting from Rex Harrison as Higgins and quite a bit from Audrey Hepburn as Eliza. Others prominent in the large but briefly-seen cast include Theodore Bikel as the Hungarian hairy hound from Budapest, Mona Washbourne as the housekeeper, Isobel Elsom as Mrs Eynesford-Hill, Jeremy Brett as Freddy, Wilfrid Hyde-White as an acceptable Pickering, Stanley Holloway as Papa Dolittle, and Gladys Cooper adequate as Higgins' mother. The screenplay was by Alan Jay Lerner, and the cinematography by Harry Stradling, Sr. The production design and the lovely, colorful art direction must be credited to Cecil Beaton and to Gene Allen in both cases; Beaton also did the fabulously-expensive costumes with Michael Neuwirth. Despite its opulence, the film has consistent style, a very good flow of events and scarcely any look about it of sound-stage claustrophobia, re-hashed stage setting or extraneously-introduced musical numbers. This is a fine late musical achievement from the studio talents that produced of Hollywood's best US musicals, and the most beautiful to watch. It could have been cold and curiously overly-polished; instead it turned out to be a rather genial classic that is genuinely fun to watch in my view, and surprisingly more interesting than one had any right to expect it could be as an on-screen extravaganza.

This review contains spoilers.My Fair Lady is a musical film directed by George Cukor and stars Rex Harrison and Audrey Hepburn. The film is about a poor Cockney flower seller and a phonetics professor that seeks to improve the flower seller's accent and place in society. The movie follows these two characters throughout its 170 minute running time. Professor Henry Higgins, played by Rex Harrison, frequently coaches Eliza Doolittle, played by Audrey Hepburn.My Fair Lady is an incredibly lengthy movie at 170 minutes of running time. I did not feel the length as the movie was frequently entertaining with its musicals. The musicals and songs help drive the narrative with each song helping the audience understand where the two characters are at. The actual plot of this movie can be squashed into a 90 minute film. Thankfully this is not the case as the length of the movie actually aids in the enjoyment of it. This movie has many other good components besides the long musicals.Audrey Hepburn does a great job with her role of Eliza Doolittle. She starts off as a low-class woman that dreams of working a flower shop. She undergoes a transformation by the end of the movie by actually evolving into the character Henry Higgins wanted. This transformation was not total as Eliza still had her own ambitions. She has a great arc through the entire running time. Audrey Hepburn also does a good job portraying the character through the highs and lows.Rex Harrison as Professor Henry Higgins does a great job as the misanthropic professor. He too undergoes a character arc and by the end of the movie comes to an appreciation for Eliza Doolittle. The character and his mannerisms are well acted by Rex Harrison. I enjoyed this character even when it seemed he was being too cruel to Eliza Doolittle. Many of the scenes involving the two main leads are great to watch and enjoy.The supporting cast of this movie does a good job. I do not think there are any weaknesses in the casting choices. All of the characters do a good job in the musical scenes they are in or offer a nice moment with the main characters.The movie can drag for audiences that are not into musicals. This movie can feel excruciatingly slow if the audience does not like musicals. To audiences that are not interested in the musical aspects, they should still give this movie a chance.I highly recommend My Fair Lady.Grade: A

I just saw MFL yesterday and liked it a lot. The main reason why this movie shines is Rex Harrison who is brilliant as Professor Hendry Higgins, who is shown as a typical male chauvinist in the first but later understands his flaws.Rex understands his character very well and doesn't go astray from his character. He totally deserves the Academy Award and many other accolades. Audrey too was good and lovable, though she could have done a bit better towards the end. The other cast too is really good.The story itself is beautiful and well-written. The songs have a story to tell and thoughts and feelings to express. The main issue with the movie is the second part, especially towards the end. There is too much concentration on Eliza's father, who too does a fine job but his character had lesser importance. There were too many songs towards the end. The director could have put one or two more songs in the first half instead.And the story does drag on unfortunately.However, its still a wonderful film. 7 out of 10 for My Fair Lady.

Review title: They waited too long to make it
Review_body: By the time the film was made, the material was ossified.  There was none of the sparkle of newness to it, but there was none of the tension that comes with re-interpretation because who would dare change a thing?  So what came to the screen was orthodoxy, already stiff because the 1960s were not the 1950s.  It was around this time that Billy Wilder filmed Irma La Douce and simply left the musical numbers out because, for the time being, Hollywood was unable to make a musical in a suitably contemporary fashion.  But My Fair Lady got made because, well, not filming My Fair Lady would have been like not filming Gone With the Wind...

Review title: "Remember that you are a human being with a soul and the divine gift of articulate speech."
Review_body: Can we bring back "squashed cabbage leaf" as an insult in 2016? It seems a lot nicer and more creative than the insults we have resorted to. My Fair Lady won Best Picture at the Academy Awards Ceremony honoring films from 1964. Considering the film was directed by George Cukor, and starring such notables as Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison, it's no wonder that it won Oscar's top prize. Couple a stellar director with an all-star cast, with a great story told in a fun way through exceptional dialogue; My Fair Lady was a tough film to beat.Opening with what seemed like a 10-minute scene of a flower montage; which in Technicolor is enough to make an allergy sufferer sneeze, My Fair Lady then transitioned to show the extravagant elegance of aristocratic theatre goers. In a brilliant conversion, Cukor then goes to great lengths to show the desolate slums just miles away. It is in these slums that we meet our heroine, a poor flower girl, Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn). When she ventures into the world of the elite to sell her flowers, Eliza happens upon a professor of linguistics, Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison). Professor Higgins has ventured to meet another professional in his field, Colonel Hugh Pickering (Wilfrid Hyde-White). After observing Eliza's thick Cockney accent, Professor Higgins makes a bet with Colonel Pickering that he can take the disheveled girl and turn her into a proper lady. He not only bets that he can turn her into a proper lady, but that he can also pass her off as a fair lady, fooling the aristocrats as her final test. Colonel Pickering agrees to the terms and tags along to oversee and assist with the transformation. Eliza puts in hours per day of work on Professor Higgins's exercises in preparation for her final test. When that day comes, and Professor Higgins takes sole credit for the transformation of Eliza, she grows cross and disappears. Through her departure, Higgins realizes that he has grown quite used to her company, and even though he fancied himself an eternal bachelor, misses her feminine company. Will the man that swore off love give in to its power?Although I admit, that parts of the storyline was a bit predictable, it unfolded in a fun charming way that kept me watching. George Cukor shows why his films have stood the test of time through My Fair Lady. The juxtaposition of the elegance of the theatre to the slums was very well done. There was a beautiful hazy shot near the end of the film when Professor Higgins realized he was in love with Eliza. He also utilized freeze frames in an imaginative way in this film, which was a joy to watch. There was a dream sequence in which Eliza, envisioning herself hopefully as a proper lady, imagines herself meeting the King. This scene was playful and well-executed to show how simple of a background Eliza came from. Although I haven't seen all the films that were nominated for Best Picture from 1964, Cukor's directorial genius displayed in My Fair Lady would have been difficult to beat.My Fair Lady was only the second musical that I have seen, yet I would recommend it to fans of musicals, and musical novices (Like me) alike. The story was well-developed and fun, the characters were endearing and easy to root for, and the technical aspects were beautiful; all of these elements came together to bring an extraordinary film worthy of Oscar's top prize. This film is a must- see for fans of George Cukor. I'm already making a mental list of more of his films to see. Likewise, no fan of Audrey Hepburn should miss this film as she is stunning and enchanting in this role. Rex Harrison seems to be an underrated actor, for reasons I cannot comprehend, and I urge those who sink into his character in this film to search him out in others. My Fair Lady is also a great film that one can easily revisit, in comparison to many Oscar winning films that I call "one watch onlys". My Fair Lady has stood the test of time and remains a fun classic that I urge you to visit or revisit.

Review title: The most creepy musical film in the history
Review_body: Every aspect of this film is obnoxious and disgusting. This is gaslighting story in which a grumpy, cranky old man keeps inculcating that Eliza's appearance is not noble, that her accent is low-class.Eliza Doolittle is portrayed repugnant as well. To make the story right, the only thing that changes after makeover is outside such as garment, accent, manner, and etc. Eliza's inside is the same, but people tend to judge based on outside. However, after Mr. Higgins' lessons, she becomes a totally different person. Audrey Hepburn's portrayal of Eliza is misleading and an eye-sore. Audrey Hepburn is only fit to have graceful and luxurious roles as you can see in the later of this movie.Music in musical film is so important, but 'My Fair Lady' fails to have any memorable and strong scores. Also, audience can obviously tell Audrey Hepburn does not sing, but it's dubbed. Choreography is non-existent and awkward if it has any. People stop during the choreography, making it so unnatural. Finally, this film is stretched without any obvious reason, this lengthy storytelling drags people out. Phonetic lesson scene is extremely long-winded that I could correct my pronunciation, too. Eliza's father's wedding scene is out of nowhere.

I bought this at a yard sale in 2013, kept putting it off thinking, "Aacck! Look how long it is! Singing and wacky accents! I should call the dentist and see if he can bump up that root canal!" I finally slapped it on...and I loved it! Rex Harrison's way of sing/talking, perfect! My favorite character: Colonel Pickering. Wilfred Hyde-White, that guy was great, a real scene stealer.Never before understood the allure of Audrey Hepburn...until now! Yeah, I'd seen Sabrina, Breakfast at Tiffany's and Wait Until Dark, all many years ago. Maybe too many years ago, now I have a greater appreciation of classic movies. She's absolutely adorable in this movie, and that one scene when she walks out dressed for the ball...jaw, meet floor! Surprised I knew half the songs already. But it has been around awhile, plenty of time to become an iconic musical. It was great, check it out if you can.

Review title: Wonderful songs and costumes, a fair lady indeed and a deliciously insufferable tutor
Review_body: I'm not an expert on the subject, having never read Shaw's play Pygmalion and being quite unfamiliar with any stage production of My Fair Lady. However, while I'm not normally a tremendous fan of musicals, I found this a wonderfully entertaining film adaptation.Of course this movie tells the tale of the English phonetics expert, Dr. Henry Higgins, who wagers with his colleague, Colonel Pickering, that he can transform the gritty Cockney flower seller, Eliza Doolittle, into a sophisticated lady simply by improving her diction, and pass her off as a Duchess at the upcoming Embassy Ball.Professor Higgins must be the most outrageous, most insufferable character ever to grace the silver screen, yet I loved this absurd champion of the Queen's English! Rex Harrison is so perfect, so hilariously entertaining in the role that I can imagine no one else filling it. I'd also sing the praises of Wilfrid Hyde-White as Higgins' kind, gentlemanly academic cohort, Colonel Pickering. Likewise, Stanley Holloway is brilliant as Eliza's ne'er do well father, that spirited scoundrel Alfred P. Doolittle.Regarding Eliza herself, there has been much controversy as to who should have been given the role, Audrey Hepburn or Julie Andrews, and I can thoroughly understand supporters of both these lovely ladies. Certainly Andrews had the voice and it has been argued, might have played the Cockney flower seller Eliza more convincingly. I feel that her career is one she can justifiably be proud of without having any regrets for missing out on the role she apparently captured so well on the stage. However, I found Hepburn perfect as Eliza and personally had no objections to her casting or any problem with the dubbing. I found her transformation from flower seller to elegant lady completely believable, her appearance stunning and demeanour impeccable at the Embassy Ball, her underlying intelligence, kindness, and wit frequently apparent, her original plight and later her unrecognized feelings for Higgins poignantly portrayed.The costumes are of course incredible, with the highlight surely being those atrocious, highly exaggerated hats at the Ascot races! In terms of the sets, I personally loved Professor Higgins' library with that spiral staircase! For me, the highlight of this film is the magnificent musical score by Lerner and Loewe. I like to leave the theatre after a musical humming one of its tunes, and there's barely a number in this one that didn't remain with me long afterward.In "Wouldn't it be Loverly", we glimpse the hardships of Eliza's life and her longing for the simple comforts and a good man to share them with, while "I Could Have Danced All Night", gives us an inkling of her burgeoning feelings for her woefully inconsiderate tutor. Where else in the musical world is there such a celebration of triumph as in the ridiculous "The Rain in Spain"? And...sigh...the light seems to finally dawn upon our Professor in his musing "I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face". However, perhaps my favourites are Alfred P's lively "With A little Bit of Luck" and "Get Me to the Church on Time", both perfect for singing in the shower!Perhaps My Fair Lady has its flaws as some claim, but I found it to be a stunning production and a timeless musical classic with unforgettable characters, gorgeous costuming, and incredibly catchy tunes. Of course there's also Audrey Hepburn, who was always such a radiant and gracious fair lady, whether on screen or off.

A full appreciation of the greatness of this movie cannot be made succinctly. Too much went into making this film one of the five best musicals of all time, on both sides of the camera.Basically, "My Fair Lady" is the story of an unwashed, unrefined flower girl who becomes the object of a bet when boisterous, arrogant, sexist Professor Higgins bets he can turn her into a proper lady in time for a big high-society party. But it becomes much more than that: the girl, Eliza, knows that she's just an item for them to bet over, and her pleas for respect go completely ignored... until she finally puts her money where her newly refined mouth is and points herself out the door.Does Higgins really have feelings for her as a human being? Will the transformation be complete? Will there be songs all over the bloomin' place?On that last one, anyway, yes. In fact, the soundtrack to "My Fair Lady" is deservedly one of the most famous in musical history, and it's rendered impressively. The only problem is in the casting of Marni Nixon to sing for Audrey Hepburn as Eliza-- Nixon is a great vocalist, but it doesn't quite match. And Hepburn's vocals (available on either of the American DVD releases), while not stunning, per se, certainly would have worked for her big cockney solo songs.Six years after film critics made the comment that a real movie version of "My Fair Lady" was unnecessary due to "Gigi," director George Cukor, and the entire crew, and the cast proved them wrong. If more movies were given this much thought, style, charisma, and elegance today, I'd probably go to the theater a lot more.Special praise must go to Hepburn, Rex Harrison, Gladys Cooper (who hilariously plays Higgins' mother), and Wilfrid Hyde-White, as well as Cecil Beaton (design), Andre Previn (musical direction), and Harry Stradling (cinematography).

Review title: The film is beautiful to watch, with excellent costumes and a delightful London-esque world built.
Review_body: This film runs a little long but there's still an enduring charm to this tale. The songs are playful and memorable, while the story is surprisingly emotionally complex.

George Cukor's much loved My Fair Lady ranks amongst the most popular of screen musicals. It's an adaptation of Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe's musical, itself based on George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion, and in keeping with Shaw's original play it's a comedy of manners. However, it hasn't aged especially well.
Pygmalion worked - and still works - because it's inherently misanthropic, with its story of a pompous, sexist (and borderline misogynistic) professor of phonetics Henry Higgins who takes on the challenge of educating uneducated flower girl Eliza Doolittle as a pet project and does so in the most patronising and arrogant fashion possible. Higgins' triumph in the play is that he succeeds; Eliza's is that in the process she gains power over him and ultimately rejects him. It's often misremembered as a love-story, but it isn't. Neither is My Fair Lady, which sticks quite closely to Shaw's play but pitches it as a comedy. The result is now vaguely distasteful: in trying to play Pygmalion for laughs, Mr Fair Lady ends up with sexual politics that are dated to say the least; a struggling Eliza being forcibly stripped and bathed is clearly meant to be funny, but quite obviously wouldn't be if it actually happened on screen.
And yet there's a quite a lot that works here. The very fact that it isn't a love story - Higgins, eventually shamed by his mother for his appalling treatment of Eliza, realises that he has grown accustomed to her presence in his life and the pair end the film as friends - makes it strikingly and refreshingly unusual amongst popular Hollywood musicals. Audrey Hepburn is effortless endearing as Eliza Doolittle and adopts a convincing - if irritating - Cockney accent. Her transformation of Eliza over the course of the film is an impressive piece of acting and she's also hilarious when playing Eliza as a screeching street urchin during her first library scene with Higgins. Rex Harrison (reprising his original stage role) is perfectly cast as the eccentric, snobbish Higgins, and his scenes with Hepburn are a delight. Stanley Holloway provides comic relief as Alfred P. Doolittle and he does a great job when he's not singing.
The singing is part of the problem with My Fair Lady, although doubtless many would disagree. Harrison does a fine job of Higgins' songs, which are interesting in that they cast light on his low opinion of women, but few things in life are more irritating than people singing in Cockney accents and thus "Wouldn't it Be Loverley?" and "With a Little Bit of Luck" in particular form painful aural assaults. Another problem is that the English cast can't compensate for the fact that the film shows a romanticised American idea of London, as the exterior sets - which are obviously sets - and costumes make plain. Having said that, musicals are rarely aiming for realism, and the huge and lavish sets used for the interiors can't help but impress. Cukor, not exactly a veteran musical director, does a solid, polished job of the film, aided considerably by Harry Stradling's dynamic camera work, which fully exploits the expansiveness of the sets, particularly during the well choreographed "Ascot Gavotte" sequence.
But for all its gloss and spectacle however, My Fair Lady doesn't live up to its reputation. It still raises a chuckle at times, but for the most part the humour falls flat; viewed now, years after it was made, it's far too long and it shows its age in all the wrong ways.

I already know I'm going to be in the minority here but this is my honest opinion of this film. The good points,Audrey Hepburn who was funny and appealing in her role,the storyline,the Marni Nixon vocals which Audrey lip-synched. Now,the rest!I watched this movie only because it won the Best Picture Oscar for 1964. I have seen all movies that have won best picture,including,"The Departed". I can honestly say though,with the exception of the good things mentioned,I have never been so bored and even more annoyed at the same time! Nearly 3 hours to tell a story that could have been told in 2? Two men wagering about turning a cockney bag lady into a lady of manner & etiquette? 3 hours of listening to Rex Harrison and his male friend "talk-sing"? He's more entertaining in "Dr. Doolittle". (In this case,I wish he had "did little". ) I had liked his acting in "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir" and wish he'd stuck to drama.I am not exaggerating when I say that by the end of this movie,I really had a headache! I have never had that happen watching a movie but that's only because other musicals I have watched may be long but have "normal" singing or they are simply 90 min. to 2 hours. Best Picture? Why? I really don't get that at all,when there were certainly more deserving films. I even like "Gigi" better than this overlong bombast! The only good songs...."The Rain In Spain","Wouldn't It Be Love-rly","With A Little Bit O'Luck" and "I'm Getting Married In the Morning".I will never,ever sit through this movie again,once was more than enough! 3 stars,period! ---------- Edit 03/02/2010 : Well,looks like I'm eating my own words,that being that I'd never watch this again. A few days ago,I decided to give this another chance and to my surprise,I somehow enjoyed it better the second time around. All I can say is that the movie didn't seem as long as it had (maybe due to being on A DVD) and songs that had gotten on my nerves didn't. I still will say that "talk-singing" does get on my nerves a bit but not like last time. So with that,I'm changing my vote to 7 stars and also apologizing to fans of this film for blasting it a few years ago. It really is a fine film. ...but my best picture choice still,would have been Zorba The Greek for 1964. (END)

Review title: As far as movie musicals go, this is one of the best ones. But, how does it hold up today?
Review_body: "My Fair Lady" (1964), back in one of my high school English classes, our teacher told us that we were going to watch this movie. I just thought: "oh, just another romantic chick-flick? This is going to be boring!" But, when the teacher put it on, I found myself fully hooked right from the get go. I was shocked to find myself completely intrigued all the way from beginning to end! Here's a little backstory: on the first day we watched it, I was so invested that the dismissal bell caught me off-guard, because I was so focused on the movie and I didn't realize what time it was! Since our class periods were 50 minutes, it took about four classes in order to finish the movie. I thoroughly enjoyed it, and most of my classmates loved it as well! Usually, most movies you watch in school or college suck. But, once in a while, you get a good one, or even a great one, and that's exactly what this film is. Before I wrote this review, I watched it again to refresh my mind with it. Still, to this day, it's such a phenomenal movie and it still retains a place on my top 10 all-time favorite movie musicals list! "My Fair Lady" has a perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and also a phenomenal soundtrack to tie it all together. Here's a little history about the story behind this film. "My Fair Lady" is based on a 1913 stage play, called "Pygmalion". It was eventually adapted into the 1956 famous stage musical and soon after that it was made into the film that we know today. The storyline is, a poor flower girl named Eliza Doolittle overhears a very stubborn phonetics teacher, named Professor Henry Higgins wagering that he can teach anyone, including her, how to speak proper English. Eliza has a strong Cockney accent, and she is taught how to speak with an upper-class English accent. Now, that sounds about as simple as you can get for a story. However, as I've said before, the simpler the plot, the better. With a simple story, it allows more room for character development and also a stronger investment from the audience with what's going on. I can tell you this, the plot is so much more than what you think. Plus, adding musical numbers to the mix really helps to keep it fresh and interesting all the way through. All of the songs are fantastic and add such an emotional layer to the story. The plot also keeps you wondering what's going to happen next. Another thing, with such a strong, yet easy to follow plot, you find yourself caring more about the characters and wanting them to succeed in the end. I don't want to say anything else at the risk of spoiling anything. But, it's a story that you'll remember for the rest of your life. As for the acting, it's nothing short of stellar from all the actors and actresses. Here's a little fun fact about the role of Eliza Doolittle. Julie Andrews, along with Rex Harrison who is in this movie, originally played the main characters in thousands of Broadway and London performances. When it was announced that a film adaptation of the musical was going to be made and Rex Harrison was cast to play Professor Henry Higgins, she wanted to play the part of Eliza for the movie adaptation. Since she knew the character and play inside out, she would've been the ideal choice. But, during that time, she wasn't that big of an actress yet. So, Audrey Hepburn was ultimately chosen to play Eliza Doolittle instead, while Juile Andrews went on to star in "Mary Poppins" (1964). I think Audrey Hepburn nailed the character, and did the film justice. Most of the movies that she stars in are incredible. She is a brilliant actress! The only thing, is that she was not a professional singer, like Julie Andrews. Her singing was dubbed by Marni Nixon. Since Audrey Hepburn has serious acting chops, it's more than easy to overlook the dubbed singing. If you look online, you can find videos of musical numbers from the movie with Audrey Hepburn's actual singing voice. I honestly think she did a decent job with singing those songs, and her voice sounded every bit as good as Marni Nixon's dub. It would have been cool to see Julie Andrews play Eliza Doolittle in the film itself. But still, Audrey Hepburn did a phenomenal job with the character! The ironic thing is, Julie Andrews won the Best Actress award for her portrayal of Mary Poppins, while Audrey Hepburn was only nominated that year. Still, if Julie Andrews had played Eliza Doolittle, then we wouldn't have gotten her iconic performance of Mary Poppins! The rest of the cast is just as strong as the lead actors, and their chemistry on-screen is impeccable. All of the sets/locations are beautiful and give the movie a stunning atmosphere. As far as the special effects go, they are perfect and still hold up to this day. Finally, the soundtrack composed by Frederick Loewe is perfect and it definitely helps bring the film to life. What else can I say about the film score? Besides the fact that Frederick Loewe really knocked it out of the park! "My Fair Lady" is a masterpiece in the world of movie musicals. It may be nearly three hours in length, but I can promise that it's one of the fastest three hours you'll ever experience with any film! Is it my favorite musical? No, there are a few that I personally like better. But, I can still watch this movie over and over again and never get tired of it. I'm giving this film 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you haven't seen "My Fair Lady", go and see it today! Now, I understand that this movie may not be for everyone. But, you should see it any way, because you just might be surprised.

The now famous musical adaptation of Pygmalion with Rex Harrison as the arrogant elocution teacher Professor Henry Higgins who bets that he can turn Cockney flower seller Audrey Hepburn into a real lady and falls in love in the process. It is truly amazing to me the kind of unbridled affection that viewers and film historians have for this adaptation of the stage musical considering how devoid of passion the final result on screen is. Director George Cukor has crafted a technically lovely looking film, but the magic is muted and the enchantment of the stage hit is sorely wanting. Harrison was tapped to recreate his stage success, but filmmakers passed over Julie Andrews to gift the role of Eliza Dolittle to non-singer Audrey Hepburn (she is dubbed by Marni Nixon). Hepburn is truly lovely here, but she is no where near the immortal asset to the film that fans like to pretend. What is amazing about My Fair Lady - the screen version - is how much it makes one think fondly of OTHER screen musicals. Life is desperately needed here and on vastly short order. For instance, Stanley Holloway's purportedly show-stopping numbers as rendered on screen have a surprisingly MEH factor. When Eliza sings effervescently that she could have "danced all night" with Higgins, what she refers to on screen is a couple of clunky turns around Higgins' cramped study. Many of the numbers are deservedly familiar, but one walks away thinking they could have been staged much better than presented - particularly against the absurdly phony backgrounds. Harrison's stuffed shirt Higgins wears thin quickly. He is arrogant, preening and obnoxious, and it is virtually impossible to root for a romantic coupling between he and Eliza. The film's strong misogynistic streak may come from the source, but the screenplay here does nothing to soften it. Eliza raises a good point when she draws Higgins' attention to the fact that now that he has raised her consciousness and turned her into a lady - what can she do now? The fact that he considers her an ingrate and gets insulted says all we need to know about a pompous, vainglorious character that fails to evolve. It says a lot when the viewer actually hopes Eliza will take up teaching and marry young aristocrat Freddy, who actually adores her for herself, rather than settle for a life of servitude with Higgins. The film's final scene with Eliza puzzlingly returning to Higgins and him barking at her to get his slippers is decidedly disheartening. A classic that is nice to see once, but whose reputation has become too bloated to be believed.

Not the movie, which is nearly unwatchable, but the glowing reviews.
I'm clearly missing something...
Higgins is nothing but a bitter old snob, and obviously gay. Even if Harrison was the actor that many pretend he was, the character is a wretch!
Pickering is the lover he never had.
Mr. Doolittle is a character that does not need to exist (what a waste of time in an already overly long movie).
Eliza could be a reasonable character, but Hepburn is about as convincing as Natalie Wood as Daisy Clover. Too old and phony.
The songs, for the most part, are terrible. I can not understand how this movie got all of the acclaim that has come it's way.
The soundtrack is just amazing. A wonderful plot. A film always memirise in mind
Audrey Hepburn Rex Harrison...enough said............

Review title: Audrey Hepburn is, and always will be, Eliza Doolittle
Review_body: While I have the highest respect for Julie Andrews, I think the producers made the right choice in Audrey Hepburn. Andrews has the clear advantage of an extraordinarily fine voice, so she could have done her own singing, as she did in the London cast recording. But I have trouble seeing Andrews as the ideal for the Eliza Doolittle character over the full scope of the movie. What My Fair Lady is about is the story of Pygmalion, the play by George Bernard Shaw, but also the earlier Greek legend of the sculptor who created the image of his perfect woman out of stone, so beautiful that she came alive. So the end result must be a very high ideal of perfection, grace and beauty.Now Julie Andrews is no slouch in those departments, but she lacks the extraordinary other-worldliness that Audrey Hepburn was renown for. When Hepburn played a real princess in her first starring role in Roman Holiday, she was absolutely convincing. She made the transformation from caterpillar to butterfly in Sabrina. So when Eliza goes to the royal ball and everyone thinks the former flower girl is a princess going incognito, it is heartbreakingly believable. Eliza truly has been transformed into the ideal of perfection and beauty. As much as I admire Andrews, I can't quite imagine her being as convincing in that scene. Some say Andrews earned the part for her portrayal of the role on stage, and that she got a raw deal. If that had been the end of her career, I would be inclined to agree. But look at the wonderful, dream roles she has had since, particularly the immortal Sound of Music, in which she was perfectly cast. I think being miscast can be as bad or worse than no role at all. While Andrews certainly would not have been a disaster, I think she might have been a slight disappointment. There is a big difference between a portrayal on stage, in which the audience is more willing to suspend disbelief, and on film, where every pore is five feet tall. That is probably why the wonderful, but aging, Mary Martin didn't get many film roles. Andrews might not have been as convincing an Eliza on film as she was on stage.I see some posters calling My Fair Lady an American production. Just a reminder: Hepburn was not American. She was British-Dutch-Belgian.
