And while she came from a rich family, she grew up in starvation poverty while in Holland during World War II, which may have given her the depth to play such a range of roles, from the flower girl to princesses. I'm not saying Hepburn's portrayal of Eliza is perfect. I grew up with Hepburn as Eliza, and she inhabits the role, in my mind. But as an adult, with the closer examination of being able to watch the DVD version an infinite number of times, I do see some weaknesses in her portrayal. I doubt most people would see these in the first or second viewing. A more troubling question is whether Hepburn should have done her own singing. She had a good singing voice, and could have done a good job. You can hear her singing Moon River in Breakfast at Tiffany's. The ultimate reason they dubbed her may have been Rex Harrison and Stanley Holloway. They are trying to make a musical, and most of the stars can't actually sing. To have a weak singing performance from Hepburn would have been too much. Marni Nixon could be counted on for a skilled voice match. (BTW, Nixon finally appears on screen in Sound of Music, as a nun commenting on Maria -- Andrews.) Problem solved.As to shortening some numbers, hey, this is a musical! The music is what it's about. I've seen too many musicals where they feel compelled to cut and cut to speed things up, shorten the movie. In South Pacific, the movie version cuts the "Wash That Man Right Out of my Hair" number down to one verse, and they really wrecked it. Brigadoon cut everything down to the minimum, and took all the wind out of the sails. With a musical, if you want to tell a story and have lots of music, you have got to make the film longer than the average non-musical; it's a big mistake to cut out parts of the story, or truncate the musical numbers. And as to the sets, the lesson I have derived from looking at many musicals is that you do not want a set that is too realistic. A musical is by nature a fantasy, because real people don't go breaking into song and dance in daily life. You need sets that are beautiful, but not entirely realistic. The 1962 remake of State Fair by Mel Ferrer, Hepburn's husband, was a disaster, and one reason was it was filmed very realistically. Guys and Dolls is perhaps the best example of non- realism, because the story was a fable, and the sets were almost like giant illustrations from a children's book. On the other hand, the movie version should not, generally, look too much like a Broadway play. Now, let's see, what would the My Fair Lady look like if the sets were a brutally realistic depiction of Edwardian London? We're talking real slums, with real horse manure. Save the realism for non-musicals.

'My Fair Lady' originated on Broadway in 1957 and was a huge successful when released. This film adaption was released in 1964 without the original star in the female lead (Julie Andrews was to star in 'Mary Poppins' and that year won the Best Actress Oscar for her portrayal). But Audrey Hepburn shines in this film as the fiery-spirited cockney flower girl Eliza Doolittle (her singing was dubbed by Marni Nixon)opposite Rex Harrison's Henry Higgins (the role he originated on Broadway). The two actors are perfect foils for each other as the student and tutor who clash over the social graces that Eliza must learn in order to be a lady. This musical is quite underrated because of Hepburn's performance as opposed to Julie Andrews' in the original production. I think that it's a matter of interpretation; both actresses have their styles and play the character in her own way. This is one of Audrey's finest performance since her performance as Holly Golightly in 'Breakfast at Tiffany's'

DVD runtime: 170 min. (Intermisssion about 2/3rds through). The film is a version of Lerner & Loewe's 1956 Broadway musical which, in turn, was a musical adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's 1916 play "Pygmalion." (Shaw's play loosely draws on Ovid's 1st century "Metamorphoses" for its plot.) Shaw was very active throughout his professional life in attacking the English class system (based very much on language & accent, as well as women's subservient role). "MFL" is in Ebert's list of "Great Films." Years ago, I bought the record album of "MFL" and the sequence of its music tells the rough outlines of the story: a financially secure, snobbish, completely non-empathic but gifted phonetics professor, Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) makes a bet with a close friend, Col. Pickering, that within 6 months he can transform Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn), a Cockney girl selling flowers, a "gutter snipe," into a lady who'll be accepted by and in upper society by changing the way she speaks. The movie shows that next 6 months as Eliza learns "proper" (i.e., upper class) speech and manners. Harrison & Holloway (the latter plays Eliza's father) reprise their roles from the Broadway musical. Hepburn's Cockney accents seemed genuine; she lip synchs her songs to Marni Nixon's actual vocals. Roger Ebert's helpful review discusses in detail the huge uproar from the choice of Hepburn instead of Julie Andrews (who played Eliza's role on Broadway), the substitution of Nixon's singing voice, and the fate of lip synching after that (plus many other interesting things). This gorgeous, stunning film adds more verses and variations to the music than that on my album. Harrison and Hepburn are simply great in their roles, as are all other supporting players including a much younger Jeremy Brett (later an older Sherlock Holmes in the PBS series) as Eliza's young aristocratic suitor, Freddy, smitten with Eliza.All the sets are magnificent. My companion had seen stage versions of "MFL" twice before but never this film -- she found the film was much richer and more satisfying. I was roughly familiar with the story but surprised to learn some things I hadn't known from the songs on the album: e.g., that Prof. Higgins had a near disastrous practice run with Eliza at the Ascot races and that something unwanted happened to Eliza's father that elevated him into the middle class.My rating is 10 of 10 stars. My only minor criticism is that I thought both of the Doolittle (Holloway) singing and dancing numbers, "With a Little Bit 'o Luck" & "Get Me to the Church on Time," went on a little too long (half would've been sufficient for me). The film nicely leaves one in doubt as to whether Eliza will go back to and stay with Higgins or marry Freddy--although maybe with a slight bias to returning to Higgins? In case you wonder what happens to Eliza in GBS's "Pygmalion" you can read Shaw's own long description of their later lives (see 'Sequel: What Happened Afterwards') following Act V (for the link, google: bartleby: Shaw, Bernard 1916 Pygmalion). And, in that same link, if you also read the 'Preface: A Professor of Phonetics,' you'll find that Shaw somewhat modeled Higgins' personality and interactions after an actual professor of phonetics, Henry Sweet, who was gifted but quite prickly --and/or, read the entire delightful "Pygmalion" play.

This is an excellent musical and movie! A treasure for mankind for all times, I think. It has everything: wonderful music, singing and dancing, excitement, romance, erudition, interesting characters, humour, first-class actors... It is also a perfect period drama with wonderful clothes, interior decoration, etc..Rex Harrison is just right as Professor Higgins, whom he plays about the same as he played Julius Caesar i Cleopatra. A strong, intelligent, ruthless, egoistic and a bit grumpy character... but in some strange way attractive to women anyway! (Harrison was entirely wrong for Doctor Doolittle, though, because the veterinarian should be quite another sort of person - nice and kind, benevolent and a little naive.) When I learned English, I used to practise by listening to audio books and plays read by the best British actors, and trying to "shadow" their voices... I wish I could have had private lessons from Professor Higgins instead! :-) ...and Audrey Hepburn was just right for Eliza. Julie Andrews would not have been right at all, because - although she was very nice-looking and likable and had a good voice for musical and everything - she did not have the ethereal beauty, regal bearing and inborn aristocracy that was necessary for the role. Elizabeth Taylor, who was also mentioned as a possible choice at the time, would have been better than Andrews but she would not have done either - because even if she had beauty and style, she was too full-figured and oozing too much sex appeal...As for the controversial ending; normally I hate when movie-makers change things, and especially endings, from plays, novels, or original movies. But in this case, it would have been much too sad if Eliza and Higgins had not come together in the end. She was in love with him, after all! It was the only possible ending, and I think it made the movie very romantic!

Review title: Hit after hit, with superlative acting and staging
Review_body: Every song in this musical is a hit. Rex Harrison is at his Rex Harrisoniest, erudite but brilliantly insufferable, and Audrey Hepburn reveals layer after layer of Eliza Doolittle. The costumes are gorgeous, particularly in the artfully-staged, hilarious scene at the racetrack. Stanley Holloway, who played Eliza's ne'er-do-well father on Broadway before bringing the role to the screen, steals his scenes. This movie earned every bit of its Best Picture Oscar and remains one of the best movie musicals of all time. The movie is not just candy, it does not dodge the philosophical class and gender implications of its story, but it refuses to be mean-spirited and, impressively, does not yet run too much afoul of modern sensibilities. If anything can be taken away from it it is its departure from George Bernard Shaw's preferred ending, but it was hardly the first production of "Pygmalion" to choose what was for many decades a more crowd-pleasing conclusion.

Best cinematography?!?!? Best director??!?!? Best picture?!?!!? It's good, but it's not that good. The two leads make the movie as good as it is. Rex Harrison makes this role his - like Tim Curry's Frank N Furter, there's no one else you can picture playing this part. Audrey Hepburn has a harder time, Cukor should have spent more time with her about her character's third-dimension ("you're supposed to be in love with this guy"). But she has a great screen presence and an intensity that you can't look away from.I think the musical steals more from The Taming of the Shrew than Pygmalion. It might have been a better idea to have gone in that direction more overtly for this film. The romances - all of them - are completely unbelieveable, except for the one between Higgins and himself.The main problem I have with this musical is that the show-stopping numbers from the supporting cast don't work at all. Harrison is a show-stopper in himself, rendering anything outside his storyline irrelevant and a waste of time. In fact, most of the numbers he is not a part of are a mistake. The "Loverly" number was given a thoroughly unoriginal and plodding treatment, Jeremy Brett's Freddy is an insipid milquetoast, and any number that Stanley Holloway is a part of is just something to be endured.

Watching Audrey Hepburn play Eliza Doolittle while Marni Nixon sings some wonderful Lerner and Loewe songs is the best of both worlds. Having undergone extensive voice training for the role, when she learned that all of her songs would be dubbed by Ms. Nixon, Audrey walked off the set in a state of bitter disappointment but humbly apologized to the cast on the next day. Class act, Audrey. Even in the worst of circumstances, she never failed to live up to our idealized image of her.While Rex Harrison "talked" his songs, often as he deliberated his feelings and impressions, and while Ms. Nixon so pleasingly intoned Hepburn's songs, the one member of the cast who actually sang his songs was Stanley Holloway, who replayed his original Broadway role as Alfred P. Doolittle, Eliza's father. Holloway was born for the role. Sporting a dustman's cap with great authenticity and then donning an elegant tuxedo for his own wedding, he stole the show with his two iconic musical numbers. Unforgettable!Unfortunately, not all of the songs in the show were as impressive as Holloway's, and, for me, a musical is only as good as its music, especially when it is brought to film. A few of the lesser tunes could have been eliminated without losing the gist of the story. The film also ran much too long with dialogue that seemed to repeat itself and actually became tiring. Eliza felt used and abused while Professor Higgins was slowly falling in love with her. Got it! No need to hammer these situations into our heads more than necessary.I also had trouble with the ending. While Harrison perfectly performs "I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face", again in that special, introspective manner, and suddenly realizes how emotionally attached he had become to Eliza, what was the message of the final scene? That Henry was still the same arrogant egotist that he had always been? Shouldn't the movie have ended with a much more confident Eliza assertively instructing him to get his own bloomin' slippers? To the very end, Henry and Eliza never enter into a physical relationship, and I suppose that was consistent with Shaw's original play, upon which this musical was based. I can somehow accept that, but what had Henry learned during the past two hours and fifty minutes of film time? Apparently, not much. He was the same pompous ass at the end that he was at the beginning.

Review title: A Great Oscar Winning Film starring Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison Warner Bros
Review_body: Jack Warner bought the movie rights to this hit musical for $5 million. A lot of money today but an astronomical amount of money in the early 60s. Cary Grant was Warner's first choice to play Henry Higgins and wanted James Cagney to come out of retirement to play Eliza's father. The leading lady role was offered to Audrey Hepburn because of her worldwide box office appeal and because quite frankly I think she was perfect for. It is shocking the way Audrey Hepburn has been treated for starring in this movie. Julie Andrews did not have any movie experience and with Cary Grant and James Cagney passing on the movie Warner Bros. Needed a great star in Hepburn as insurance. The sets are magnificent the costumes are magical the music is legendary and all of this was done at the Warner Bros. Studio in Burbank. PS I am still thunderstruck on the artful way Covent Garden was created pn Burbank soundstage.The movie justly was awarded the best picture Oscar: Rex Harrison deserved and won the best actor and Audrey Hepburn should have been nominated at least.Jack Warner personally produced this great movie bringing Cecil Beats in to do the sets. Covent Garden is recreated on WB stages in Burbank.George Cukor won his long deserved OscarThis is moviemaking at its best in Hollywood had the fairest of fair ladies in beautiful, magical, legendary in Audrey Hepburn.This is a great Movie.

I am a huge fan of musical films. There are very few musicals I did not like. My Fair Lady is the best I have ever seen. The story is great as is the screenplay. It has been readone many, many times and I truly understand why. The screenplay makes you really care about the characters. They are all characters we love, and will always love. The performances are wonderful, particularly Audrey Herpburns. She gives what is very possibly her best performance. She catches every little moment and movement. She knows her character front to back and maybe even beyond that. The direction is also extremely good. The shots are beautiful. Passes up so many of the other great musical movies like Moulin Rouge and The Sound of Music.

I grew up loving this musical. It's the story of two linguistic professors who make a bet that they can pass a flower girl off as a duchess at a royal ball by giving her speech lessons.I have read comments that say it's a misogynist movie. I disagree. I think it's actually a feminist movie. Here is Eliza Doolittle, who goes through hell to make a better life for herself. She leaves Henry Higgins after he takes credit for her hard work. (spoiler) When she does return at the end of the movie, it's on her terms, not his.Favorite moment in the movie: Eliza singing "Just you Wait, Henry Higgins" and getting caught imagining his demise! Favorite Song in the movie: "Wouldn't it be loverly"

Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) is an extraordinarily egocentric and misogynistic phonetics professor who makes a bet with his more reserved colleague Colonel Pickering (Wilfred Hyde-White) that he can pass off vulgar Cockney flower girl Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn) as a duchess at the Embassy Ball in three months' time. Hijinks, personal conflicts, and romance ensues as Eliza struggles to prove herself to be more than just a "gutter-snipe", and Higgins is forced to face the fact that he may not be the end-all be-all of planet Earth."My Fair Lady" is such a beautiful film to watch, with an extremely interesting story (based, of course, on Shaw's "Pygmalion"), a fine cast, and beautiful art direction and cinematography. And yet. . . it's a musical. That's my number one problem with the whole thing. I don't necessarily have anything against musicals, though I'm not a huge fan of the genre, but one still can't help feeling that a straight adaptation of this material would have been better.The song score is made up of classic songs - classic, in that they were/are very popular and have been done and re-done hundreds, if not thousands, of times. Yeah, excuse my cynicism, but it's hard for me to consider them truly classic when I can barely remember them an hour after the movie is over. There are some nice songs, namely "Show Me", "Why Can't the English", and my favorite, "Just You Wait, Henry Higgins", that are highly memorable, but most of the show's other major songs are fairly typical Broadway show tunes. There's also the issue that some of the song's are superfluous and/or overlong. "I Could Have Danced All Night" is a nice little song that goes on for about two minutes too long.And then there's the subplot involving Eliza's father Alfred (Stanley Holloway), who goes from a money-grubbing, womanizing, lazy bum to a rich lecturer (thanks in large part to a practical joke by Higgins) - a sort of counterpart to Eliza's transformation into an affluent society girl. Holloway is great in the role, and his character is amusing, but his two songs - "A Little Bit of Luck" and "I'm Getting Married in the Morning" - go on way too long and add little to the story.Another problem I have with the film is the ending, which I'll not spoil, but I don't think it's really true to the characters or the way the story develops.My problems with the songs aside, "My Fair Lady" is such a gorgeous film that one is reluctant to criticize it. The sets are wonderfully authentic, capturing Edwardian England perfectly; the costumes are some of the most gorgeous ever put on film, and George Cukor's direction is nothing short of brilliant. Most of the characters are very well-drawn and believable. Audrey Hepburn makes an unbelievably lovely Eliza; she is convincing both as the foul-mouthed flower girl and the polished débutante who wants to find true love and recognition. This is perhaps her signature role (despite her songs being dubbed), and it's easy to see why. Rex Harrison nails the part of Higgins perfectly, though to be fair, he had a lot of practice on Broadway. Wilfred Hyde-White and Stanley Holloway also create memorable characters.But for me, the regrettable banality of the film's songs will prevent me from claiming it a masterpiece. I will always wonder if "My Fair Lady" had been a straight adaptation of "Pygmalion", with the same cast - I've no doubt that would have been a masterpiece. But much as I love aspects of it, I cannot call "My Fair Lady" a truly great film.7/10.

Review title: Flower girl in "high society" or How one bet changed a whole life
Review_body:
Musical. A screen adaptation of the Broadway musical of the same name by Frederick Lowe, in turn based on the play "Pygmalion" by the famous writer and playwright of British-Irish descent Bernard Shaw. I have nothing to say about the play and the musical, since I have not read the first and have not watched the second, so I will evaluate the picture as an independent work, following the spirit of the original sources. Shine! Fantasy! A miracle of wonders and a guarantee of a good mood for a few days, maybe even weeks. No, I'm not crazy, it's all true. And here's my brief opinion - Creep in "high society". There are no shortcomings in this masterpiece, but there are some remarks, which I will mention in a separate paragraph, but for now, allow your humble servant to focus your attention on the expressive merits of this masterpiece musical.
So, here they are:
1. The story told - the beginning of the twentieth century. London. Two wealthy gentlemen decide to make a bet. They have to make a real high society lady out of a street seller of flowers in six months, and none of the "high society" should suspect deception. The poor flower girl is given a unique chance to drastically change her own life and transform herself literally before our eyes. I have no right to disclose the details and turns of the script, because I do not want to spoil the viewing for those who have not yet deigned to evaluate this masterpiece. I will just say that everything will be here: romance, humor, songs (many songs, a lot of songs), great acting, amazing music and an expressive ending that will not leave you indifferent to everything that happens!
2. Audrey Hepburn - how could you impress me even more than in "Breakfast and Tiffany", "Roman Holiday", "How to Steal a Million", "Stories of a Nun", and indeed in any picture? Amazing talent and mastery of transformation. Play a street grubby, rude and hysterical and soon reincarnate as a refined lady. A delicate flower that should be cared for and cherished, but not in any way subjected to such humiliations that will be here. I am sure that many of the scenes were purely Audrey's improvisation, since this is simply impossible to predict. I have no exact information about this, but an inner voice tells me that it is. And who am I to argue with that.
3. Humor - in many places I laughed heartily, and sometimes it was not even laughter, but hysterical laughter that was impossible to stop. Witty, ironic, funny and guarantees the production of endorphins in your body. There are many funny situations that will make you smile and brighten up hard working days.
4. Songs are a musical, especially of the mid-twentieth century, so there are many songs, but here there are even more. I can't say I liked all of them, but most were good, especially Audrey's evil song in the first third of the picture. The rest fit perfectly into the light (and sometimes not so) mood of the picture. I also liked a few songs of the minor characters.
5. Music - it is taken from the musical of the same name, therefore it perfectly conveys the atmosphere of the next variation of "Cinderella". The music is light, beautiful and catchy, especially the title theme.
6. Scenery and Costumes - London was not real, and only the studio scenery played its role, and it shows. But competent placement, surroundings and little things convince the viewer that this is London from the beginning to the very end. The costumes are perfect, especially for the beautiful Audrey! And how they suit her, especially a hat with flowers! Unforgettably!
7. Charismatic heroes - both first and second plan. They are all perfectly written and remembered. Yes, there are pure caricatures, but there are also banal ones, but this does not interfere with the perception of everything that happens. Each has its own character, with strengths and weaknesses that are obvious.
8. Romance - it runs through the whole picture like a thin thread and in the final is revealed in all its glory. Two so dissimilar people who are drawn to each other, but one of them does not admit this to the last, although the heart and soul by this moment are already screaming with love. All romance develops logically, and is not taken out of thin air, as in most modern paintings, where it must always be present.
A little about the main characters:
1. Eliza Doolittle performed by Audrey Hepburn is a street flower girl, rude in her tongue, who turns from a grubby into a real lady with an ideal voice and manners, striking everyone on the spot with her dazzling beauty. Audrey's talent breathed a second life into Eliza and made both of them famous for years to come. Bravo Audrey! Bravo and a whole pen!
2. Henry Higgins performed by Rex Harrison is a professor of literature and a staunch bachelor who, out of scientific interest, made an interesting bet with a friend. Still not suspecting that this will drastically turn not only his life, but also everyone around him. I remember Rex from the magnificent role of Caesar from the masterpiece of historical cinema "Cleopatra" in 1963, but here he played a brave and self-confident aristocrat with a scientific vein, completely devoid of romance (as he thought). Bravo Rex! Bravo!
In several places, the picture was able to knock a tear out of me, especially at the moment when the heroine realized that there would be no return to the past.
Regarding comments. It would not hurt to shorten the picture, for about twenty minutes so precisely, since some of the scenes are already too stretched. You can safely cut out a few songs that do not carry a new semantic load. Since this way the picture looks protracted, and at some moments even boring.
Why was this masterpiece released only on DVD in Russia? I demand to publish it in blu-ray format with a restored picture, with Russian subtitles for songs and additional materials that will allow you to look at the other side of the camera. And the new generation of viewers does not bother to get acquainted with this classic of world cinema, which, among other things, received eight Oscar awards, and each one is absolutely deserved!
Despite the above remarks, I cannot change the final grade and put it below tens, forgive me. I'm in love!
Well Audrey! I also looked at three pictures with your participation, and I liked all of them. But I haven't watched "Sabrina" yet and a few other works that praise you. I will definitely fill this gap. Kiss and love!
As a result, we have a masterpiece musical based on the classics of world literature, with an excellent script, great humor, exciting songs, great romance and great acting, including Rex Harrison and incomparable Audrey Hepburn!
My rating is 10 out of 10 and my recommendation for viewing!

Musicals.  You don't see them much at all anymore.  They're have been very few in the last few years but they are usually so enjoyable to watch. Chicago even won best picture.  Why do they not make these anymore I wonder? This film was awesome.  Hepburn is a great actress and her movies are wonderful.  To see her play two different types of people in this movie was very enjoyable.  Even though it was nearly 3 hours I was entertained the whole time.  Go out and see this movie and do it soon.  We need to bring more musicals back.

Very few movies are letter-perfect. Not perfect in the sense that goofs and gaffes don't exist here and there, but perfect as in pure entertainment. Especially in long movies, the squirm element is always a threat. "My Fair Lady", bringing the most tuneful of Broadway scores to the big screen (really big, at the time) was as perfect as movie entertainment could be. The old furors over Audrey Hepburn seem silly in hindsight. Hepburn replaced Julie Andrews, a wonderful singer-actress who had created the role, not only on Broadway but in London. But Andrews was not a familiar face to movie-goers and no one knew if she'd hold an audience in the movies as in the live theaters. Too, Hepburn was an inspired choice, since her background probably would make Eliza Doolittle's transformation from flower-selling gutter-snipe into a lady of quality more believable (Hepburn's mother was a baroness). As far as her singing voice, the new DVDs of "MFL" have her acting to her own recordings of a few of the songs, and while it's not bad, at this level of film-making expense and prestige, "not bad" is no good.Surrounding her are a magnificent cast. Stage and screen pros Rex Harrison (Henry Higgins) and Stanley Holloway (Doolittle) were carried over from Broadway (after some initial and rather foolish questions about both). Joining them were veteran droll actor Wilfred Hyde-White as Col. Pickering and an amazingly youthful Jeremy Brett ("Sherlock Holmes") as Freddy.The book and lyrics were by Alan Jay Lerner and the music by Frederick Loewe ("Brigadoon", "Camelot", "Gigi", etc.) based on George B. Shaw's best play. A fully "integrated" musical where the songs advance the story or reveal character, the nonpareil line-up of songs include "I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face", "The Rain in Spain", "I Could Have Danced All Night" and "On the Street Where You Live".Because of its theatrical origins there is an unavoidable stage-bound look to some scenes. But the designers have done their best to keep this from being a detriment. The interiors look like real houses, the Covent Garden set is a masterpiece of openness. Only the Ascot scene retains its staginess, but its black and white palate and stylized look adds variety to the movie.The restored DVD version looks great. I saw a print of this movie in a revival theater in the early 1980s; it was blurry and broken and the colors were faded and inaccurate. Yet the designers used a rich tapestry of colors and wood tones, giving every corner of the movie's wide screen something worth seeing. "MFL" was a spectacle well worth the struggle and expense of restoration. Everything about "MFL" was first-class, the cast, script, costuming, sets, music. For someone who enjoys musical there's not a dull moment.

I think people are being rather churlish about Audrey because they still resent Julie not getting the part. But this was around 40 years ago so can we forgive and forget? Particularly since Julie, in an obvious sympathy vote got the Academy Award that year (for Mary Poppins) and Audrey wasn't even nominated. Yes, Audrey was dubbed and Marni Nixon (the dubber) on the DVD speaks at great lengths about how it was done. Also included on the DVD are Audrey's actual vocals of "Loverly" and "Show Me". While she wasn't bad in the first, the second was somewhat beyond her vocal ability.In fact, it seems that Audrey might have originated the role on Broadway were it not for a false rumor that she was pregnant at the time. Incidentally, John Gielgud remarked, in one of his letters, that he thought Audrey was better than Julie!I thought the film was excellent, dubbing or not, and the casting was also excellent. I had two small reservations about the film: The first was the fantasy scene where Audrey-Marni sang "Just you wite, 'enry 'iggins" which Cukor hated and with good reason. It should have been done without the oil on the lens and probably without the "enactment". The other was the race at Ascot where the horses were shown briefly twice and perhaps the turning binoculars would have been sufficient and funnier as on the stage.But I suppose they didn't want to appear "cheap".The ending was, I think, pretty close to the film of Pygmalion and the musical was based on the film and not the play (in which I think Eliza marries Freddie.) I do think there's a certain amount of ambiguity in this ending and I don't think Shaw's estate would have allowed much else. G.B.S. himself would not have accepted Eliza marrying Henry and he said as much.According to the DVD, Cecil Beaton, who did actually design the stage sets, did virtually nothing on the movie except take the credit and a terrific still of Audrey in costume according to the commentary. In effect, the DVD plays the film over while 4 people (Gene Allen the art director of the original film and Cukor's assistant, the restorers Robert A. Harris and James C. Katz and the aforementioned Miss Nixon.) comment on each scene and I think that's overkill but one doesn't have to watch it. As for me, I could have done with less on the restoration but enjoyed the comments on the actual shooting of the movie especially on Audrey, Rex and the various other players and extras.9 for the film and DVD.

Review title: Lovely Songs and Great Acting Make for a Great Musical
Review_body: If you are the sort who despises musicals, the stop reading right now and turn around. This movie is a deserved classic, with a smoothly-flowing story and perfect acting. I enjoyed this film much more than "Mary Poppins," and felt that Ms. Hepburn deserved the Oscar for her portrayal of the gutsy, proud Cockney flower girl Eliza. Rex Harrison is great as the stuffy, equally-proud linguist Henry Higgins. This movie remains faithful to George Bernard Shaw's satiric vision, where class can be denoted through simple language and dialect. Higgins is a wonderful caricature of the stodgy upper class, who looks with contempt on those below him, and fails to regard the feelings of those people, like Eliza. Eliza is less a caricature (again, not being English, I know little of the stereotypes of the cockneys), and her transformation in the film is credible, in spite of the "refinement" of her dialect. The songs are all classic, and you may find yourself singing along with the tunes. Audrey Hepburn, well into her thirties, is gorgeous and stunning to behold: a great actress and a genuine Hollywood beauty. This film represents the last golden era of cinema musicals, and is well worth your time.

Based on the play by Shaw, this really is a gem of film-making from the 1960s musical era. It's hard to go wrong with Rex Harrison and above all the divine Audrey Hepburn.In this ignorance-to-education story, a diamond in the rough is taken from gutter snipe to lady, mainly by teaching language. The conceit is that you are what you talk like.The tension arises because dear Mr. 'Enry 'Iggins, a self-declared language expert and Eliza's teacher and foil, is really a pretty nasty character: sexist, rough-mannered, although he thinks of himself as the epitome of humanity. His best excuse is that "he does it to everyone equally." Not quite true, he treats his male friend Hyde-White certainly better than his housekeeper or poor Eliza.The film features awesome songs (maybe one out of a dozen or so is meh, the rest are among the best Broadway has ever seen), amazing costumes, and a caterpillar-to-butterfly transformation of Audrey Hepburn's character that leaves the viewer spellbound the whole time. The side characters, like the puffed-up Hungarian count who seeks to demask Eliza, Higgins' mother, who knows what an ornery fellow her son is, Eliza's dad, an intelligent but downtrodden free spirit, are all nicely drawn.Modern audiences will find Higgins a bit grating - he remains unrepentant and a sexist pig to the last - but hey, times were not as politically correct in the early 20th century, when Britain was still lording it over India and suffragettes were marching through the streets demanding the women's vote. The movie is an interesting stylized vignette of turn-of-the-century British society both low and high, as conceived by George Bernard Shaw and viewed through the lens of the 60s, and the cinematography, music, acting, singing and the hats, oh the hats, are all amazing.

Review title: The quintessential musical with a staggering pedigree.
Review_body:
The classic case of an embarrassment of riches.  The infrastructure of this jewel reads like a Who's Who of American Cinema. Take the play by George Bernard Shaw.  It's in the Western Canon of Literature, for heaven's sake.  Then add lyrics by Jay Lerner and his longtime collaborator composer Frederick Loewe who gave us everything from An American in Paris, to Gigi, to Brigadoon, among many others. 
Directed by George Cuckor, whose credits include not only Gone With the Wind, but also a string of Katherine Hepburn films, My Fair Lady bears Cuckor's brilliant touch in directing leading women.  And what a leading woman he had to work with this time.  Audrey is breathtaking in every move and every syllable she utters.  But that's not all.  Those stunning costumes designed by Cecil Beaton are without peer in modern cinema, especially the Ball Gown.  Audrey was so exquisite that she looked unreal, perhaps of another species, as she descended the stairs and donned her velvet cape.With music direction by Andre Previn, the baton behind Gigi, Porgy and Bess, Kiss Me Kate and even Jesus Christ Superstar, My Fair Lady's musical pedigree is complete. From this perspective, My Fair Lady is the culmination of a generation of America musicals, and the greatest one of them all even before the first frame was filmed.Ironically, Audrey was denied a well-deserved Oscar.  She didn't even get nominated, which from an historical perspective boggles the mind.  The Oscar that year went to Julie Andrews for Mary Poppins.  Andrews, who had popularized the role of Eliza Doolittle on Broadway before the movie was made, passed on My Fair Lady to do Mary Poppins.  Andrews, a gifted singer, was reportedly miffed at the casting of Hepburn, whose singing was dubbed by an uncredited Marne Nixon, and Hepburn's exuberant performance was completely ignored by the SAG.But there were enough Oscars to go around.  Beaton, Harrison and Previn all collected statuettes, and My Fair Lady collected eight total and was nominated for four more.  This immense achievement was almost lost to deterioration, but the newly restored version is stunning.  If you don't have this one in your collection, you can't call it a collection.

Review title: I don't care if my friend make fun of me but I love this movie
Review_body: This is one of the best if not the best musical out there. Rex Harrison did was perfect and Audrey Hepburn could not have been funnier. There are very few times when I actually stop by to admire the costumes, but the costumes are one of my favorite parts of the movie and in a way really move the story forward and gives us endless character development. The race track scene is one of my favorite scenes of all time and everything about it is perfect. The costumes of course (I love how Rex Harrison's suit stands out in an almost garish way), and the lighting and choreography of the scene. There are very few times when I actually think that the placements of the extras was perfect, but it was in this scene. I could talk about this scene all day, but I will move on. The songs are surprisingly catchy and not over the top (like Hello Dolly). I liked how the dance numbers involved people that could not really dance and really looked like people off the street. The last thing I want to point out is one of standout moments of the movie is when the street is just getting going in the morning and the extras freeze in waves and then start moving. I love that scene and regard it as one of the more original scenes in any movie I have seen. The end was also nice because unlike more "romantic comedies" did not have the big mushy moment at the end but ended with grace with a very personal moment shared by two people that loved each other.

Review title: Lots of catchy songs, but short on substance!
Review_body: Just saw the 3 hour 1964 version of this movie on VHS. First impression was Audrey looked too clean and her teeth too good to be a desperate little flower peddler on the streets of old London. The movie was colorful, but the studio sets were too obvious, especially the horse race scenes. The movie was overly long and many of the musical numbers were neither compelling to watch nor advancing of storyline. The relationship between Eliza and Professor Higgins was odd and nearly nonsensical. He was obviously too old to be a serious romantic contender, yet there was some underlying and unresolved emotional attraction between the two that was not adequately explained. Therefore, the ending scene where Eliza has come back is unsatisfying and confusing. Is she to become Mr. Higgins maid, mistress, or live-in pet? It's not clear and none of these possibilities seems very plausible.Cut some of the lesser songs and scenes that don't advance the plot. Concentrate more on the dramatic metamorphoses of a low class peasant girl into a radiant princess and explore the psychological effects they have on her. I dunno....this movie didn't work for me. If not for the on screen appeal of Audrey, I could not have watched this movie."On the Street Where You Live" is one of my all time favorite musical songs. Loved Vic Damone's version. But watching the scenes in the movie that included this song proved disappointing. The actor singing the song was shot long, full view in shadowy street sets. Therefore, no facial emotion was seen to go along with the full bodied emotions characteristic of the song.

56 years later it is still, amusing. entertaining, educating and a bulletproof guidance (*) on "how to make a success". A - from the depth of my heart - "thank you" to everyone involved, in any way, with this jewel.
(*) A guidance is useful for those who primely can READ! Which is not he case with today's producers.
If you don't believe me, keep a note on what IMDB is proposing TODAY in the front page and try to find ANYTHING about that next year, same day!

Review title: THE GREAT REX IN A LOVERLY FILM
Review_body: What more can one say? Rex Harrison owns this film,do we really care if julie or audrey played liza when watching the master Shavian work his magic? Harrison has played everything from Ceasar to THE GHOST AND MRS. MUIR  to BLYTHE SPIRIT and he was a brilliant actor,here he pulls out all the stops! charming,pig headed,arrogant and in many ways child like the oscar belonged to him hands down,he earned it. Yes, andrews would have been better than hepburn but audrey is a good actress and tried her best. Stanley Holloway and Gladys Cooper are brilliant in their supporting roles and wilfed hyde white is quite a funny,befuddled pickering. oh, and lest we forget the pre-holmesian jeremy brett,so good as the love struck eynsfoed-hill?Splendid costumes by ir Cecil Beaton are a treat for th eye. and of course no one writes lyrics like alan lerner,his style was all his own..and oh, yes, thank you Shaw for providing pygmailion,without it we would have no FAIR LADY to praise.

"All I want is a room somewhere, far away from the cold night air..."Early on, as a humble flower girl, Eliza's wants are simple. And it seems she has a fair to good chance of seeing them satisfied.That of course is before Henry Higgins takes her under his wing. (...no, that's not the right metaphor. How about, "puts her under his whip"?) Eliza becomes a person without a spiritual home (as poignantly conveyed by a scene in which she returns to her old haunts, and nobody recognizes her), with complex wants (centering on a love-hate relationship with Higgins) and scant satisfaction. She is someone who, if we look beyond the ambiguous ending of the movie, is likely to undergo torment for years, possibly a nervous breakdown.Eliza was better off selling flowers in Covent Garden.This realization casts the movie in a quite different light, as a tragedy perhaps. But then it's a musical, the viewer is probably not expected to take it too seriously, and on that level it is indeed quite "loverly" (can't get that tune out of my head...don't want to, either).Taken seriously, it's a different kind of movie entirely; and, as much as I like Henry Higgins' quick wit, in real life I would have to condemn him as among the cruelest of men. ...OK, OK, don't take it seriously...and then it's8/10

First of all, I love Audrey Hepburn, symbol of elegance. This musical is so pure.story is a little long and super cliché for our year but in '64, probably it was unique. Actually I don't like all songs, rain in Spain is my favorite in the movie. Last I wanna tell about wardrobe, it is just perfect, fenomenale, beyond time, not only Eliza's clothes, every single piece is incredible, hats, hair accessories, men's toxidos.... I love this classic movie and I feel so lucky for watching this masterpiece.

Review title: Very well done because Shaw's searing social commentaries made it into the dialog and amazingly, even into the music.
Review_body: Loewe's name should have been up there in the IMDb credits beside that of Lerner. The tunes of this musical movie are simply unforgettable. And, assisted by the lyrics of Lerner which hewed closely (sometimes even exactly) to the social commentaries of Shaw, the songs are gems.As a young man, my favorite was On the Street Where You Live but I couldn't help being attracted to With a Little Bit of Luck because Stanley Holloway and his crew were simply a riot with their words and antics in this campy and scampy number.Holloway stole the thunder from everyone (even from the venerable Rex Harrison) each time he appeared on a scene. That repartee between him and Harrison (Prof. Higgins) where he chided the latter about his "middle class morality" is pure Bernard Shaw social commentary. I simply love his cockney accent and I don't think that rib-tickling song I'm Getting Married in the Morning could be sung without it. I believe he got an Oscar (supporting actor) for his role in this film.

It does drag in many places.  Plenty of scenes could have been trimmed. Audrey Hepburn's Cockney accent is very annoying,  (It sounds so much better when Marni Nixon dubs it for the songs Wouldn't It Be loverly? and Just You Wait.), and unfortunately, once she loses it, she has to speak some very artificial dialogue.  Other than that, tough, nothing really wrong with it. Great songs, delicius one-liners, and excellent performances.  Rex Harrison is wonderful, Audrey is charming (even with the Cockney accent and artificial dialogue), Stanley Holloway is great, though his numbers don't really add anything (But are still fun!), and Gladys Cooper is also good. Definitly a good movie, though those mentioned flaws stop it from being great, unfortunately.

A musical adaptation of a tale of love between a book-learned pedagogue and a flower-selling prodigy bonded through phonetics.The movie is a melange of mellifluous songs, male chauvinism and a maiden who undergoes a paradigm shift in her speech and charisma.I love the scene in which people are busy with their daily chores and the frame freezes, then the camera zooms out and another set of people move around and then it freezes and another set of people move around. And all the people in the 3 sets of the frame move around in a haphazard manner.I beg your pardon lovers of literature, I haven't read the play by George Bernard Shaw nor have i heard about it before watching the film.Professor Higgins takes Eliza as a disciple to experiment on after Col. Pickering throws a challenge that he couldn't make a duchess out of a flower-seller. Professor Higgins, an expert in Phonetics, is a celibate and often looks down on women. He provides her luxury and at the same time forces her to try and try till she enunciates the words correctly. After several exhaustive sessions, Higgins makes her perceive what they're trying to do to her and his words do the miracle. She speaks flawlessly and with a rich and refined voice.Higgins takes her to a horse race, a place where Eliza could interact with the blue-blooded. She does well in the beginning but slowly she starts uttering innuendos and senseless idioms that Higgins and Pickering try to cover up with illogical explanations. Things go back to round one when she screams in enjoyment in the language of the slum-dwellers. Higgins gives her rigorous training and his efforts bear fruit in a matter of time. She draws the attention of several people and a princess showers encomiums on her charisma.Higgins is lauded for his efforts by his fellowmen but they fail to understand Eliza's efforts too; all that she had to endure to become a subject of Higgins' achievement. She leaves the house in agony and swears to never return again. Higgins realizes they are in-execrable but takes time to confess it and comes to him after his long-due confession.

What a production.....the musics, the actings of rex harrison n audrey hepburn and the awesome directing synchronisation n super whelming lyrics.....simply astounding and overwhelming.....i loved it a lot!

I don't think there is an element of My Fair Lady that anyone cannot love or admire. Perhaps you like the catchy, joyful tunes. Or maybe you enjoy the gorgeous vintage fashions. Or instead the Cinderella-style story line? Are you an Audrey/Rex fan? Do you like funny lines? Or are you really into classic movies/musicals? There are so many more reasons why you should see this movie. With so many wonderful musical compositions it is undoubtedly one of the most successful, enjoyable and watchable musicals of all time. It is not corny, it is realistic - unlike some other musicals. Audrey Hepburn is wonderful in this - most of the cast is, really. So you don't have to worry about crappy acting and actually feeling sorry for the actors making complete fools of themselves! You don't have to worry about listening to a boring tune. It is such a lovely musical to watch, I recommend it to everyone. And if you don't like musicals, why don't you take a look at this one? It could change you mind. It is a wonderful movie that you can watch over and over again.

Although her singing voice is absent, Audrey Hepburn carries this 1964 adaptation of the famed play with the precision of her diction. Whether warbling through her vowels in torturous cockney squeaks or betraying just a hint of the street in studied dulcet tones afore a rapt royal audience, Hepburn conveys Eliza Doolittle's essential struggle for self, precariously adrift between the person she's pretending to be and her irrepressibly sweet impish nature. In this, a story in which each character's social role is earmarked by their earnestness in upholding acceptable conversational dialect, what we need to know about Eliza at any given moment must be conveyed by the sound of her words. At her best, as in a rebuff to doe-eyed suitor Freddy, these words show a wounded dignity that is heartbreaking. In her pursuit of a better life, she allows herself to be transformed beyond recognition by Henry Higgins. The essential question of the story is whether one can be truly content, no matter how auspicious the environment, in the absence of a true identity. Hepburn convinces in the struggle to find the answer to this question, one we all must answer at some point.

Review title: A classic musical beautifully filmed and restored.
Review_body: George Cukor's production of My Fair Lady is one of the last of a vanished breed. Beautifully made films of Broadway musicals are relics of a bygone age. Luckily, My Fair Lady was restored to its loverly 70MM splendor just a few years ago and now it can be seen on video reproduced from that superb Super Panavision print.  The two current video incarnations (from 2oth Century-Fox Home Entertainment on laserdisc and Warner Home Video on DVD) are both superb renderings. Rex Harrison's portrayal of Henry Higgins is one of the gems that was preserved from the stage production. We'll never know what Julie Andrews would have done with Eliza Dolittle on the screen, but Audrey Hepburn has nothing to be ashamed of. Her Eliza glows, especially in her scenes at the Embassy Ball and the Ascot races. The score that Lerner & Loewe composed to bring Shaw's Pygmalion to musical life is virtually perfect.  The orchestrations and vocal performances in the film do complete justice to the original. The sets and costumes by Cecil Beaton elaborate on his fine designs for the stage production. The deluxe laserdisc contains an excellect documentary detailing the history of My Fair Lady and its filming.  The newly released DVD has an illuminating commentary by restorers, Robert A. Harris and James C. Katz, art director, Gene Allen, and vocal double for Miss Hepburn, Marni Nixon.  In addition, you can hear what Audrey Hepburn would have sounded like had they used her vocal tracks on the supplementary material on both the DVD and deluxe laserdisc. My Fair Lady is surely an example of the type of film we'll probably never see again. The best they can do is what they did to "Cats" in its recently filmed version. It's just not the same. My Fair Lady remains a musical wonder presented in all its appropriate lushness and reverence for the classic that it is.

By the 1960s, musicals were beginning to sour with the audiences. The great boys and girls of song and dance yesteryear were phasing out. Gene Kelly, Judy Garland and Ginger Rogers were trying their hand at straight dramatic acting, with varied success. Fred Astaire took his top hat and tails somewhere else. Shirley Jones too found her feet out of musical roles and the careers of all at the musical stable plunged with the sad death of the greatest shows on earth.We still had beloved Julie Andrews. Three stage successes. "The Boy Friend" and "Camelot". But Eliza in "My Fair Lady" was for years her best and most defining trademark role. Because life isn't like "42nd Street", Julie didn't get to play Eliza.
For box office insurance, Warner wanted Cary Grant. Similar circumstances prevailed two years before when they asked for Grant for "The Music Man". Therefore, in part by using Rex Harrison, despite the fact he was not potent box office, was the wisest move they made, along with employing Stanley Holloway to reprise his role. Both perform with great zeal in the roles they were simply born to play. Audrey Hepburn remains one of the greatest actresses of her time. Like all good actors, she summoned personal experience to bring life to the roles. As one of literal fashion ambassadors of her time, she failed oddly to combine tomboyish simplicity and gamine chic with her Eliza. Her accent was horrifying, and in general, her performance lacked the smallest elements of Julie's legendary characterisation. Marni Nixon even, usually doing great cover up jobs by dubbing the non-singers, sounds absolutely atrocious in comparison to Andrews. This is a musical comedy, but instead I found suddenly, various unknown pains never experienced while listening to the original Broadway recording of Julie in "My Fair Lady". The Eliza songs lack the depth and beautiful quality that made Julie Eliza and not Audrey. The screenplay was bogged down by boring length in some parts, which simply made an unsuccessful attempt to remain faithful to the stage. On the other hand, it tried to keep intact the piercing social classes commentary of 1912s England. This on all accounts fails.If anyone was capable of mounting a great production of style and elegance in the 30s and 40s, it would be George Cukor. By employing the use of sickening colour cinematography, mediocre sets and costumes, and in short, commissioning a below average screenplay, it is merely a blow to his great career. Even the Lerner and Loewe musical score, one of my all time favourites, is uninspiring and flat. The whole thing should never have been mounted, but by not snapping up these rights it would be similar to passing over "Gone With the Wind". "My Fair Lady" would have worked to better effect in the 50s as opposed to fast changing attitudes towards musicals of the 60s. Although the 1964 Academy Awards was the night for "My Fair Lady", both "Dr. Strangelove" and "Mary Poppins" would have suited better to take out the statuette for Best Picture of 1964.I can't complain entirely, actually. I don't know what I would do if Julie wasn't in "The Sound of Music". Rating: 3/10

I remember all the media coverage of this movie in 1964--mainly the controversy of Warner Brothers mogul, Jack Warner, choosing actress Audrey Hepburn over Julie Andews to play the major star role of Eliza Doolittle. Hepburn was known mainly as a dramatic performer. No one had ever heard her sing before and of course, in "My Fair Lady", the main female role called for lots of singing.
Warner explained that Hepburn was a first class "movie star" who had proven her mettle in a string of successes and that she was perfectly suited for the challenging role of the street urchin who becomes a grand lady at the hands of a grand gentleman.
Warner was still in the old Hollywood mode of signing up talent with a "box office" name, whether they were right for the part or not. He never explained that the main female performer most associated with the Broadway version of this movie was the brilliant and British Julie Andrews. She had already won numerous awards for her performance, had made the Broadway cast recording into a huge success.
The many news articles all mentioned Julie Andrews didn't need anyone dubbing her. She had a voice that was truly phenomenal.
So when the finished product was finally ready to be seen by the public--the $17 million musical did look sumptuous on the screen. Although it still resembled a filmed stage production in many ways and although the costumes and interiors and sets were eye-popping, the sight of Audrey Hepburn mouthing the lyrics to a song performed by Marnix Nixon, was jarring.
Hepburn looked as if she was performing like a robot all the quirks an scowls and bellows that her character was supposed to make--but when she opened her mouth to sing, her lip-synching was sometimes a little off.
Dubbing a movie musical for actors and actresses is as old as talkie movies from the late 1920s. Who can forget the controversy over "South Pacific" where every single performer, except for Mitzi Gaynor, were dubbed. In "West Side Story", same thing with the exception of Rita Moreno.
But Hepburn was the centerpiece of "My Fair Lady" and one would think that at least the performer who took on that major role could at least carry a tune.
Which is why, I think, Julie Andews became a superstar with both "Mary Poppins" and especially the spectacular 'Sound of Music." The audience Knew she was doing her own singing with no fake help of dubbing.
For movie musical lovers, "My Fair Lady" is a painless pleasure but that nagging knowledge that the main female star is faking her own vocalizing will always be a shadow over thoroughly enjoying it.

Review title: All I want is a...different Eliza
Review_body: This is a great musical, very colorful with wonderful songs and setting and story.The problem is that it seems backwards to me. That is, Audrey Hepburn was a great beauty no matter what clothes she wore or what her voice sounded like. Beautiful is beautiful. So to see her gussied up like the Queen of the Universe at the conclusion of the film just confirmed what you already knew.Why don't these films (Ms. Congeniality is another one) that take lovely actresses, try to make them plain, and then revert them to what they never stopped being to start with, try just once to really transform somebody? Hey, what are Holly Hunter or Kathy Bates doing lately? I am no fan of Julie Andrews but she did earn this role. Audrey Hepburn was too gorgeous, unable to sing, and thus unbelievable. Well, it was all long ago. My question is, who was Hepburn's voice? Marnie Nixon? I could find no attribution on the video. A rather petty omission, as everyone knew it wasn't Audrey warbling she, "could have danced all night."

Review title: Where's Julie Andrews When You Need Her?
Review_body: "My Fair Lady", is an icon of the Broadway musical stage. The film version is less than mediocre, and sadly, the only permanent visual record of this stage masterpiece. It is obvious that no expense was spared in bringing this show to the screen, but what does it matter? The entire production is so slowly paced and unexciting, that you feel that director George Cukor (who won an undeserved Oscar), embalmed the show. Horribly studio-bound, there is nothing that distinguishes this as a film. It is void of everything that made the show an exciting stage experience. Many of the sets, look like sets, and the make-up, hairstyles and many of the costumes on the women is very 1960's and silly looking for 1912. Eliza Doolittle is the heart and soul of this musical, but Audrey Hepburn's performance of her is so false, that the very life of the show is gone. She's all wide-eyes and and inappropriate smiles (watch the LOVERLY number), with carefully placed smudges. She growls and clenches her fists when she's supposed to; but it just ends up being Audrey Hepburn play acting at being Eliza. She never, ever makes you think she IS Eliza. Also, her accent is wrong. She would never have fooled anyone, with her "European" sounding English accent. The dubbing of Miss Hepburn (done after the film was made), is almost as bad as watching a "Godzilla" movie. It always looks out of sync, and never sounds right. When one remembers Broadway's original Eliza, Julie Andrews (who should have been in this film), it makes Hepburn's casting even harder to take. Rex Harrison and the supporting cast are first rate; but it is Eliza who must be perfect, and she isn't. Hepburn's miscasting, Cukor's plodding direction, and the failure to recognize that they were making a film, make this a disappointment of the highest degree. NOT recommended!

For all generations there will never be a greater musical film than "My Fair Lady". Not "The Sound of Music", not "The King and I", not "Oliver!" not even "West Side Story" can compare to the soaring music, striking costumes and lavish sets of this musical masterpiece that won eight academy awards including Best Picture, Best Actor (Rex Harrison) and Best Director (George Cukor). Audrey Hepburn is brilliant as Eliza Doolittle and thanks to help Marni Nixon she makes Julie Andrews sound barely admissible. I think Audrey was robbed of her chance at the Oscar nomination for "Fair Lady" and I curse all those who thought that she was not that great as Eliza. The film might not have been as great a success if Audrey were not chosen for the part. Julie was great in "Mary Poppins" but I can't see her as Eliza on film. I grew up hearing how brilliant she was on stage but I purchased the Broadway cast album about three years ago ('96) and felt that Julie was fine on stage but not in the film.  Audrey is the fairest "Fair Lady" and she always will be!

Ugh!We had to watch this movie is drama to learn about voice tones or accents...something about voice (even though in my drama class we never really acted anything out except once but that was it...oh well.)Anyways...this movie almost put me to sleep.That woman was so annoying, her voice...just her! She got on my damn nerves!The singing was annoying too.I like the musical movies (i.e- The Wizard Of Oz, The Sound Of Music) but this one's plot was just stupid and the singing got annoying fast.I gave it 3/10
Insufferably long and obnoxious acting. If you like the movie plot, but want to see it done better then watch Pygmalion 1938.

Based on the Shaw play Pygmalion,  this great Broadway musical starred Julie Andrews, who for some reason is NOT in this film version, this musical still soars.  Filled with memorable songs and scenes, and featuring Rex Harrison in perhaps his greatest role, this is a touching musical about language and feeling. It sounds austere but it ain't. Go out and rent it!

This is one of the best musicals I have ever seen! Audrey Hepburn is the street dirt-turned royalty Eliza Dolittle and Rex Harrison is the selfish, nimble-minded Professor Higgins. Freddy Einsyford Hill, played by Jeremy Brett, is the adorable and rather handsome young man who falls for Eliza Dolittle as well. Hepburn and Harrison stole the show, and even though Ms. Hepburn was ad-libbed by Marni Nixon for the singing parts, it didn't really show in the movie. Rex did a wonderful job as Pro. Higgins, and Jeremy Brett.... Well, he was absolutely terrific. I watched this movie for the first time with my best friend, and this movie made me a HUGE fan of Ms. Hepburn. A must-see for all of her fans. Kudos to everyone who was in this movie. It was excellent.

-My Fair Lady- is close to perfection if it isn't there. Some may dislike it because they dissent with George Bernard Shaw's premise that language is the most obvious sign of social class in 19th-century Britain. People could have lots of money and be 'low'; someone with the right sort of speech can fool others about one's origins. If one fails to accept this premise, then the movie fails miserably. I accept Shaw's premise that language is nearly everything. Rex Harrison excels in his role as 'Henry Higgins', a pedantic expert who believes that by changing the speech patterns of the lowliest flowermonger 'Eliza Doolittle' (Audrey Hepburn), who must surrender all of the certainties of her proletarian life (including getting away with her low-class speech) to prove her benefactor's theories true. Note well that any slipup in the role ensures that we see Higgins as an unspeakably cruel man performing an unethical experiment. Somehow one can believe his thesis that by changing the speech one can change everything and transform a flowermonger into a debutante -- but we must also feel Eliza's distress at the effort to change her. Sure, it's slow, as noted -- demonstrating how difficult a task Henry Higgins has given himself... and, of course, Eliza Doolittle. Clearly, Higgins has far less to lose than Doolittle. Changing thirty years of 'bad' habits doesn't come easily.What does the experiment achieve? Partial success. Maybe there is more to change than language, as at the horsetrack scene, where Eliza Doolittle charms the superficial characters of the upper crust with her trivialities, only to bring out her proletarian roots to the fore when she gets emotionally involved with the horse race {"Move your bloomin' @rse!").Finally, Eliza Doolittle gets exposed by one of Higgins' rivals, 'Zoltan Karpathy', (Theodore Bikel), who gets to hear the results of the experiment and concludes that she is a fake -- too good to be true as an Englishwoman! She must be --- Hungarian!Henry Higgins gives all the credit to himself, and none to the one who took the greater sacrifices for little assurance of benefits. That begins a course of events that lead in directions that he can't foresee (and which are spoilers).Is Audrey Hepburn too good to be true? Sure -- she was then spectacularly beautiful once one took her out of rags and put her into 'classier' attire. Could Higgins have succeeded with an older, less-attractive woman? I doubt it. Shaw's contention that language is everything -- more than the content of one's thoughts, more than money, more than years of habits, and more than attractiveness isn't 100% true. But it's close!.

Review title: A Nice Film but Not the Greatest as Many Say
Review_body:
I've had an interesting relationship with this movie over the young years of my life and I still have mixed feelings about it. My Fair Lady is often cited as one of the greatest films of all time, or at the very least "the only perfect musical." Its impact on film culture is indeed undeniable but I agree with the late Robert Osbourne of Turner Classic Movies. He stated that it is a nice movie but it is not essential and it has many problems its contemporaries could have overcome better than this. But I will try to be Fair to the film.The story involves street urchin Eliza (Audrey Hepburn) who's cockney is so thick her peers even comment on it. By happenstance, she encounters an arrogant phonetic expert, Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) who believes a person's manner of speech is what separates urchin from duchess. They strike a bargain that he can teach her to speak like a princess and pass her off as one to prove his theory, whereas she could possibly gain proper employment at a flower shop. Their relationship is fraught as both are headstrong and stubborn, but eventually she "gets it" and speaks properly. But the question arises: Will Higgin's views and strict teachings help or hinder her?I'll start off with the elements of the film that work very well for me. Rex Harrison nails a mysonginistic character with a heart, he doesn't seem all that aware that what he's saying is hurtful as his passion for what he does blinds him to the heart of the woman he's trying to mold. The supporting cast is decently assembled, with the standout supporting player being Stanley Holloway as Eliza's ne'er do-well alcoholic father Alfie, who gives the movie life it desperately needs at times. I am of the opinion that almost any score from the great duo of Lerner and Lowe is going to be absolutely wonderful and this movie is no exception. There are smatterings of brilliance in the dialogue and the story development but unfortunately this leads into many of the movie's problems.Chief among the films problems is it is far too overblown. The same issue arises in films like Seven Brides for Seven Brothers and Hello Dolly, the issue of large sets and huge casts of hundreds in costume but have zero zest to them and come off as way to stylized to make an emotional connection. There is a difference between portraying aristocrats with a slight tongue in cheek attitude and then theres this movie where I laughed with incredulity at how people could possibly think this is a great movie. I like George Cukor as a director but here, he tends to keep his cast and sets in medium shots and even wide shots, which does nothing to help the story. And when there are close-ups they are uncomfortable when they are meant to be endearing and vice-versa.I need to address the elephant in the room and discuss Audrey Hepburn's performance and how it ties the the story. I love Audrey Hepburn and when she speaks the part, she is interesting and almost compelling. I do not mind that she was dubbed but Jack Warner made a horrific decision to do so for two reasons: 1) It sounds like most of the cast was not dubbed by someone else (save for Jeremy Brett which itself is odd) thus her dubbing sticks out like a sore thumb
2) Yes Julie Andrews was passed over and once people saw her in Mary Poppins it didn't seem right when the talent was there and an executive didn't even give her a chance to screen test for it
However, this is not my issue with the story or Hepburn's performance, but rather Alan Jay Lerner's screenplay. The dialogue sparkles and the characters established, but the narrative is hopelessly weak as opposed to its source material, Shaw's Pygmalion. Eliza starts as a stubborn urchin who yearns for a life better than rescuing her flowers from puddles. However, she is constantly seen as less than by Higgins, and she decides to strike out on her own. Good for you! But then she decides to complain to his mom and rub it in his face like a woman scorned, which doesn't strike me as a logical progression for her character. And the ending cripples a possibly progressive and powerful message that Shaw achieved wonderfully.So my final thoughts are this. I'm glad this movie means so much for people and it nearly clicked with me, but too many things just prevented me from embracing it. I do not think it was the best film of 1964 by any stretch. I think Mary Poppins, Dr. Strangelove, and even Becket were better films which took risks and delivered something better than this film. I'm glad I've seen it and I even hum some of the songs once and a while, but My Fair Lady isn't a perfect flower for me.

Rex Harrison is clearly the ONLY person who could ever successfully play Professor Higgins. He doesn't sing, he doesn't dance, and he barely acts. But somehow, he just makes it so darn enjoyable!And of course, Audrey Hepburn is great. Okay, even for Broadway, this story is a little uneven at the edges, and downright hokey at times. But like I said, it's entertaining .. it's fun to watch. And the music is great!Oh, by the way, it's so bizarre to find out that Marni Nixon did all the singing. She also sang for The King and I, and for Westside Story. Before I read the trivia on IMDB, I had never even heard of her. She does all that wonderful singing and she's a no-name? Go figure.

It seems hard to believe (among us aging Baby Boomers, that is)that the opulent film version of the famed Broadway musical "My Fair Lady" is nearing the 40th anniversary of its original release.When the movie premiered at NY City's Criterion Theatre in late October of 1964, the excitement anticipating its release was almost equal to the commotion that greeted the opening of "Gone With The Wind" in 1939. Producer Jack L. Warner spared no expense in transferring the Lerner and Loewe musical adaptation of Shaw's stage play "Pygmalion" to the screen. At the then astronomical cost of 17 million dollars, the Warner Brothers Studio artisans created the Edwardian world of Covent Garden, 27A Wimpole Street and environs into some of the most spectacular indoor sets ever created for the movies. Veteran cinematographer Harry Stradling captured all this in glorious Technicolor and Super Panavision 70, his camera lovingly recording for posterity Cecil Beaton's sets and costumes, lavish embellishments of the Broadway show. George Cukor, Hollywood's much revered "Woman's Director" guided his actors to thoroughly professional performances, with Rex Harrison dominating the film with his unforgettable portrayal of phonetics expert Henry Higgins, that irascible middle-aged bachelor who wagers a bet with an eminent colleague that in three months he can pass off a hapless flower girl into a duchess at an Embassy Ball. That flower girl, played in the movie by the lovely Audrey Hepburn, was a huge casting bone of contention among critics and public alike. Jack Warner hired Hepburn despite protestations that the original Broadway Eliza Doolittle, Julie Andrews, should repeat her memorable stage performance. But Andrews had never acted in movies, and Warner wanted to hedge his bets with a known name and quantity. In one of the great ironies of movie history, Julie Andrews took Hollywood by storm, starring in Walt Disney's own expensive musical extravaganza, "Mary Poppins", which beat "Fair Lady' to the screen a month earlier. It was "My Fair Lady", however, that triumphed at the April 5th, 1965 Oscar ceremony, winning 8 Academy Awards including the coveted Best Picture prize. In a delicious moment of sweet revenge, Julie Andrews picked up the Best Actress award for playing the titular Mary Poppins, the magical English nanny of her own Edwardian England. The other great irony in all this was that Audrey Hepburn failed to receive a Best Actress nomination for her very able work in "Fair Lady ". The question will always remain whether Andrews would have made "My Fair Lady " a better film.Perhaps so. But Hepburn is luminous, especially her transformation into a proper English Lady, where she really comes into her own. Her singing voice is dubbed by Marni Nixon, a prolific "ghost singer" for many actresses in film musicals who were not up to snuff in warbling demanding Broadway songs. Both "My Fair Lady" and "Mary Poppins" were the Crown Jewel entertainments of 1964, a time when the United States was still healing from the terrible emotional scars of the assassination of President Kennedy the year before. Some critics quibbled at the time that producer Warner embalmed "My Fair Lady" more than preserved it.Yes, it's stagy in the old fashioned Hollywood sense of the word. It's also a Grand Show that in its original 70 mm presentation was a visual knockout, something hard to duplicate in this age of Home Theatre Entertainment. The movie preserves for posterity one of the most brilliant musicals ever created, and with Rex Harrison's Henry Higgins, one of the greatest stage performances of all time.

As a rule I absolutely despise musicals. The idea that people are talking and then, suddenly, burst into song would be enough, in the real world, to send for the looney wagon. But I must admit that, whenever MFL is shown on TV, I usually click on to it several times during the showing to try and catch some of the great songs. I could not care less about the storyline or what becomes of any of the characters. Marni Nixon has always been a favorite of mine and she has a voice that is stronger and much more pleasant than that of Julie Andrews, who was rejected by the film's producers for the role of Liza. I also enjoy Stanley Holloway and I was certainly perplexed when I read that he was not the first choice to play Liza's dad in the film. With their typical thirst for "name recognition" type actors, the part was actually offered to James Cagney who, wisely, turned it down.

40th Minute, tears dropping.
Maybe more than twenty years have passed away since...
Certainly my English language skills aren't the same.
Maybe I am in need of a real spoken English teaching, all those marvelous accents I could have had been in contact except that I actually have not had the chance to meet them.
"For I, being poor..."
But today I prefer to spend my nothingness in, regarding such thrilling performances.
Because my teacher are you, distinguished participants of the commonly called cinema or, the broader sense of the seventh art.
It will be reviewed later, after watching it thoroughly.
Good riddance to those departed, to those alive, thriving, and especially godspeed to those initiating the path.
Thanks to G. Bernard Shaw, George Cukor, Rex Harrison, to all crew, and with honors, and a lot melancholy, to Audrey Hepburn.

My Fair Lady is a great movie with unforgettable music, stars, costumes, and sets. Audrey Hepburn is a lovely and talented actress and she does a fine job as Eliza Doolittle. I think, however, that she was too 'delicate' for the role, and I was, for the first and only time disappointed with Miss Hepburn's performance. In all honesty, I admit my prejudice for having twice seen Julie Andrews' spectacular performance on Broadway.
Audrey is my favorite and this is one of her best performances of her career. She is stunning in this film! The movie is so unique and it has nice music that goes great with the story.

It is strange to me that My Fair Lady has built up so much acclaim over the years. It's charming enough in its own witty way, but there is so much lacking here it is hard to believe that some people really consider it one of the best musicals of all time. In fact, the only reason I gave it a 7 and not a 6 is because of Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison. Their charm alone is enough to elevate it to classic status, and perhaps that is why the movie has lasted so long and so high up in the ranks.Audrey Hepburn is Eliza Doolittle, a dirt poor flower girl who meets Professor Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) on the street one evening when he severely criticizes her pronunciation of the English language. The song at this point in the story, "Why Can't the English," is one of the best in the play, but in the movie it is strangely boring and flat. It seems to me to be a directorial problem- he didn't know what to do with it so therefore he did nothing. It so happens that Professor Higgins meets the esteemed Col. Pickering (Wilfrid Hyde-White) on that same night on the same street, and the Col. makes a bet with the Professor that he cannot make a lady out of Ms. Doolittle. And so follows many a song and clever banter.Audrey Hepburn is wonderful as Eliza, there's no question about that.
